choices.text: High carbohydrate diet > Mixed diet > High fat diet
Mixed diet > High fat diet > High carbohydrate diet
High fat diet > High carbohydrates diet> Mixed diet
High carbohydrate diet < High-fat diet > Mixed diet

questions.text: A 23-year-old male is willing to participate in a marathon. He has had no previous exposure to strenuous exercise, so he visited his dietitian for consultation to improve his physical efficiency. Which of these dietary patterns is true in this regard?
questions.solution:
To optimize endurance for marathon runners, a high carbohydrate diet is essential. It enhances glycogen storage in muscles, providing sustained energy during prolonged physical activity. Therefore, the correct answer is option A. Individuals consuming high- carbohydrate diets generally exhibit superior glycogen reserves compared to those on mixed or high-fat diets.

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Page Number-1086.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with a mildly painful swelling over the scalp for 2 months as shown in the image. Which of the following could be the causative organism ?
questions.solution:
• Tinea capitis is an infection of the scalp hair caused by dermatophyte fungi such as Trichophyton and Microsporumspp.
  • Kerion is a severe inflammatory form of tinea capitis with a hypersensitivity reaction against dermatophytes.
  • Kerion is usually associated with infection by zoophilic dermatophytes,
  • It is a red boggy swelling,mildly/non tender, studded with pustules with easy pluckability of hair and regional lymphadenopathy - Kerion
  • IOC: KOH scraping
  • TOC: Griseofulvin

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, , 9th Edition, Page Number- 32

choices.text: Compressed air pushed in front of the current

questions.text: All the following can cause injuries in a lightning flash except -
questions.solution:
According to Spencer, there are 4 factors that result in injury in a lightning flash.

  1. Direct effect of high voltage current.
  2. Burning by superheated air.
  3. Effect of expanded and repelled air around the flash.
  4. Compressed air pushed before the current produced by lightning.

Even individuals quite remote from the flash may sustain injuries due to the effect of the compressed air.

The primary burn is usually on the head and may be diffuse or the injury may be simply in the form of bruising usually at the back of the head, which may be attributed to ‘sledge hammer blow’ dealt by the compressed air pushed before the current (Spencer).

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology by K.S. Narayan Reddy; 35th Edition, Page Number-257; Textbook of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology by Krishan Vij, 5th Edition, Page Number-141.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions the ovaries function normally?
questions.solution:
• In MRKH syndrome, there is mullerian agenesis but the ovaries are present and they function normally.
  • In Turner and Swyer syndrome there are bilateral streak gonads.

questions.text: After the death of her husband, a 60-year-old lady was brought to the OPD by her sons with complaints that she has become more religious, spiritual and gives lots of money in donations. She now believes that she has a goal to change the society. She is involved in into many activities and sleeps only for 3 hours. She does not like being brought to the hospital and is argumentative on being questioned about her doings. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: The defining characteristics of mania are increased talkativeness, rapid speech, decreased need for sleep, racing thoughts, distractibility, increase in goal-directed activity, and psychomotor agitation. Some other hallmarks of mania are an elevated or expansive mood, mood lability, impulsivity, irritability, and grandiosity.

choices.text: Call for help -check carotid pulse and breathing -give CPR
Leave the person, go looking for a friend and come back to the scene

questions.text: A doctor goes for a morning walk and finds a person unconscious in the park. Which of the following is correct about CPR?
questions.solution:
According to BLS guidelines, the following steps are to be followed:

  1. Scene safety should be checked.
  2. Check for the responsiveness of the patient by shaking the patient
  3. Shout for help from the surroundings.
  4. Activate Emergency Response System.
  5. Look for carotid pulse and breathing
  6. Start CPR if there is no pulse and breathing-30 compressions and 2 rescue breaths.
  7. Continue cycles until AED arrives.

questions.text: Dwarf tapeworm refers to:
questions.solution:
The term "dwarf tapeworm" refers to Hymenolepis nana. It is the smallest intestinal cestode that infects humans. Understanding the specific characteristics of different parasites is essential for accurate diagnosis and treatment.


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page Number-128.

questions.text: All the following structures form the boundaries of the infraclavicular fossa except-
questions.solution:
The infraclavicular fossa, also known as the deltopectoral triangle, is a triangular depression situated below the junction of the lateral and middle thirds of the clavicle. It is anatomically defined by the pectoralis major medially, the anterior fibers of the deltoid laterally, and the clavicle superiorly. However, the medial border of the 1st rib is not a boundary of the infraclavicular fossa.


Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia: Human Anatomy, Volume-1, 8th Edition, Page Number-37.

questions.text: The unit of measurement for CT scan is-
questions.solution:
In the realm of CT (Computed Tomography) scans, the unit of measurement is Hounsfield Units (HU). Named after Sir Godfrey Hounsfield, HU represents the radiodensity values assigned to different tissues. This scale proved instrumental in discerning between tissues based on their X-ray attenuation properties. It essentially provides a numerical representation of tissue density, aiding radiologists in interpreting CT images with precision.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive Textbook of Diagnostic Radiology, 2nd Edition, Page Number-308.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of nocturnal enuresis in children?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of nocturnal enuresis (bedwetting) in children is often related to maturational delay of bladder control, exacerbated by psychological stress. Delayed maturity of neurons is a common factor, and stress can contribute to this condition. While urinary tract infections, spina bifida, and diabetes mellitus can contribute to enuresis, psychological stress is often a significant factor, especially in children.

Reference: OP Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition, Page Number-527.

questions.text: A severely injured patient presents with a spinal fracture and is unconscious. What is the first step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
In trauma situations, the initial management follows the ABCDE approach (Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, Exposure). Spinal stabilization is a critical aspect of the "C" (Cervical spine) in ABCDE. The use of a cervical collar helps prevent further movement of the spine, reducing the risk of additional injury during transportation.

Reference: Fundamentals of Ortho by Mohindra & Jain, 5th Edition, Page Number-41.

questions.text: During the infiltration of a local anesthetic, the highest chance of increased systemic concentration depending on the site of injection is by which of the following?
questions.solution:
The site of local anesthetic infiltration significantly influences systemic concentration. Among the options, intravenous administration poses the highest risk of increased systemic concentration. Understanding the varying rates of absorption at different injection sites is crucial for anesthetists to ensure patient safety during procedures involving local anesthetics.

Reference: Morgan & Mikhail's Clinical Anaesthesiology, 6th Edition, Page Number-267.

choices.text: Fasciotomy can be performed after 24 hours of entrapment
Prolonged crushing of muscle leads to a reperfusion injury when the casualty is rescued
The myoglobinuria that occurs, leads to renal failure from tubular obstruction
A mannitol-alkaline diuresis of up to 8 litres per day should be maintained

questions.text: All the following statements are correct regarding crush syndrome except:
questions.solution:
OPTION A- A late fasciotomy, when it is obvious that the muscles of that compartment must be dead, is only likely to cause a massive release of myoglobin, as well as potentially introducing infection into the dead tissue.

Therefore, it is best NOT to perform a fasciotomy in cases where entrapment has been for over 12 hours.

  • Prolonged crushing of muscle leads to a reperfusion injury when the casualty is rescued (Option B).
  • This releases myoglobin and vasoactive mediators into the circulation. It also sequesters many liters of fluid, reducing the intravascular volume and resulting in renal vasoconstriction and ischemia. The myoglobinuria leads to renal failure from tubular obstruction. (Option C)
  • The treatment of crushed casualties should begin as soon as they are discovered. Rescuers must be alert to the presence of associated injuries.
  • Aggressive volume- loading of patients, preferably before extrication, is the best treatment. After provision of first aid and starting intravenous fluids, the patient should be catheterized to measure urine output. In adults, a saline infusion of 1000-1500 mL per hour should be initiated. This should be continued until myoglobin is no longer detectable in the urine.
  • Mannitol administration can reduce the reperfusion component of this injury. Once a flow of urine is observed, a mannitol-alkaline diuresis of up to 8 liters per day should be maintained, keeping the urinary pH greater than 6.5.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page Number-458.

questions.text: A drug that binds to a receptor at a site distinct from the active site, and alters the affinity of the receptor for the endogenous ligand is called as?
questions.solution:
Allosteric modulators show high selectivity for distinct receptor subtypes. These agents exert their pharmacological actions by altering the affinity or efficacy of orthosteric muscarinic ligands.

Positive allosteric modulators (PAMs) enhance orthosteric activity, while negative allosteric modulators (NAMs) inhibit it. Allosteric agents that can directly activate muscarinic receptors are termed allosteric agonists.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th Edition, Page Number-150.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presented with gradually progressive, painless loss of vision in her right eye for one year. She was a known case of VHL syndrome. On fundus examination, temporal to the disc, a saccular grape-like cluster of thin-walled angiomatous lesions were noted, extending to the ora serrata. Image of histopathology of the same is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Cavernous hemangiomas are composed of large, dilated vascular channels. On histologic examination, the mass is sharply delineated but unencapsulated and is composed of large, cavernous blood-filled vascular spaces, separated by connective tissue stroma. Cavernous hemangiomas are one component of von Hippel-Lindau disease, in which vascular lesions are commonly found in various organs.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page Number 519- 520.

questions.text: What is the reference to which census population count is undertaken?
questions.solution:
As the population numeration is carried out from 8-28th February and stopped on 1st March, the point at which the numeration is completed is called as Census Stop, or the moment of 00:00 hrs of 1st March.

Incorrect options:

  • 5th June (Option C):
    • World environment day.
  • 1st July (Option B):
    • July 1st is used to measure the mid-year population.
  • 1st January (Option D):
    • January 1st is too early in the year.

questions.text: A 45-year-old obese woman presents to her primary care physician with complaints of fatigue, right upper quadrant abdominal pain, and a feeling of fullness after meals. She denies alcohol consumption but admits to a sedentary lifestyle, and a diet high in processed foods and sugary beverages. On physical examination, she had hepatomegaly. Laboratory investigations revealed elevated liver enzymes, with alanine aminotransferase (ALT) levels at 120 U/L (normal range: 7-56 U/L) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) levels at 90 U/L (normal range: 5-40 U/L). A lipid profile demonstrates elevated triglyceride levels at 300 mg/dL (normal range: <150 mg/dL). Which of the following laboratory findings would be consistent with a diagnosis of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD)?
questions.solution:
• Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is characterized by the accumulation of fat in the liver in people without the habit of alcohol consumption.
  • It encompasses a spectrum of liver abnormalities, ranging from simple steatosis (fatty liver) to non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) and cirrhosis.
  • Elevated serum gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT) levels are commonly observed in NAFLD.
  • GGT is an enzyme found predominantly in the liver and bile ducts.
  • In NAFLD, elevated GGT levels are indicative of liver cell injury along with intrahepatic duct injury due to advancement of disease. It also increases due to inflammation and oxidative stress.

    • Incorrect options-

  • Option A) Serum albumin levels are typically normal or slightly decreased in NAFLD, especially in advanced stages when the liver function is impaired.
  • Option B) Serum ferritin levels are typically normal or elevated in NAFLD, as they can be elevated in the setting of obesity and insulin resistance.
  • Option D) NAFLD is associated with insulin resistance and often manifests with elevated serum glucose levels, rather than decreased levels.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page Number-254.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old male patient presenting with hearing loss was subjected to audiometry. His audiogram is shown below


What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The above audiometry graph shows a notch at 4000 Hz in both AC and BC curves. This is typically seen in noise induced hearing loss. Dip at 2000 Hz in the BC curve is seen in Otosclerosis (Carhart’s Notch).

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P L Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page Number-41.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is responsible for converting light into neural signals in the retina?
questions.solution:
• Rods and cones in the retina are responsible for converting light into neural signals.
  • Rods are more sensitive to low light conditions, while cones are responsible for color vision and visual acuity.

questions.text: Acetylation and deacetylation of lysine residues on histone proteins provide one mechanism by which transcription can be activated or repressed. Which one of the histone proteins is least likely to participate in this process?
questions.solution:
• Nucleosomes are disk shaped particles that consist of a core of histone protein which are positively charged and around which DNA is wrapped, which is negatively charged.
  • A short linker region of DNA joins nucleosomes.
  • The core of the nucleosomes is made up of two copies each of histones H2A, H2B, H3, and H4.
  • These histone proteins have N-terminal "tails" that contain lysine residues that can be reversibly acetylated, become negatively charged, and affect the electrostatic interaction of the DNA with the histones. DNA is repelled from the histone core.
  • Histone H1 is not a part of the nucleosomes core, therefore, acetylation would likely not affect the protein–DNA interaction of the nucleosomes.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews: Biochemistry, 7th Edition, Page Number-425. Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page Number-361.

questions.text: A case of carcinoma larynx presents with the involvement of left vocal cord, left aryepiglottic fold, left ventricular band and invades into the paraglottic space. Which of the following statements is true for the management in this case?
questions.solution:
This is the stage T3 laryngeal carcinoma as paraglottic space is involved.

The treatment of choice for T3 and T4 cancer larynx is total laryngectomy followed by radiotherapy.

However, certain cancer study groups recommend the use of concurrent chemoradiation with cisplatin for T3 cancer larynx as an alternative to total laryngectomy though, the 5 year survival rate with concurrent chemoradiation is lower when compared to surgical management.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P L Dhingra, 8TH Edition, Page Number 363-364.

questions.solution:
Posner Schlossman syndrome-

  • Atypical uveitis with minimal inflammation.

questions.text:
Arrange the following stages of deglutition in the correct order:
1. Initiation of primary peristaltic wave.
2. Palatopharyngeal folds on each side of the pharynx are pulled medially to approximate each other.
3. Initiation of secondary peristaltic wave.
4. Vocal cords of the larynx are strongly approximated, and the larynx is pulled upward and anteriorly by neck muscles.
questions.solution:
The correct order of the stages of deglutition is option B - 2,4,1,3. The voluntary stage (2) initiates swallowing, followed by the involuntary pharyngeal stage (4) involving strong vocal cord approximation and laryngeal movement. The esophageal stage comprises primary (1) and secondary (3) peristaltic waves. This coordinated sequence ensures efficient and safe passage of swallowed material from the mouth to the stomach.

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Page Number-798, 799.

questions.text: The scab/crust in an abrasion wound is brown-black after;
questions.solution:
Age of abrasions -

  • Fresh - Bright red
  • 12 to 24 hours - Lymph and blood dries up leaving a bright red scab
  • 2 to 3 days - Reddish-brown scab
  • 4 to 7 days - Dark brown to brownish-black scab. Epithelium grows and covers defects under the scab.
  • After 7 days - Scab dries, shrinks and falls out.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology by Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page Number-136.

questions.text: A primigravida came to the OPD with her report showing an increase in beta hCG and decreased PAPP-A levels at 12 weeks of pregnancy. She can be complicated with which of the following?
questions.solution:

Reference: Fernando Aria's Practical Guide to High-Risk Pregnancy & Delivery, 5th Edition, Page Number-4.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female complains of progressive weight gain, fatigue, postural dizziness, loss of memory, slow speech, dry skin, constipation, and cold intolerance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms, including weight gain, fatigue, slow speech, and cold intolerance, strongly suggest hypothyroidism. This condition results from decreased thyroid hormone levels, impacting various physiological systems. The signs and symptoms described are characteristic of hypothyroidism, often referred to as myxedema.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition, Page Number-344.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is not used to detect the presence of primer metal components on the hands of the individual who fired the firearm?
questions.solution:
The gunshot residues on the hand of the person who fired a gun are derived from both primer and gunpowder (propellant).

Dermal Nitrate or Paraffin test or Diphenylamine test is used to detect gunpowder (Nitrous compound detection).

The primer contains metal compounds which can be detected by -

  • Harrison and Gilroy Test
  • NAA (Neutron Activation Analysis)
  • FAAS (Flameless Atomic Absorption Spectrometry)
  • TMDT (Trace Metal Detection Test)
  • SEM-EDX (Scanning Electron Microscope-Energy Dispersion X-Ray) - Best Method.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology by Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page Number 180, 181.

questions.text: Which of the following is the effect of the SRY gene?
questions.solution:
• The SRY gene is located on the short arm of chromosome Y.
  • It turns undifferentiated gonads into testes.
  • Target gene for SRY which favors testes differentiation: SOX 9
  • Target gene for SRY which favors ovaries differentiation: WnT4, Rspo, DAX

questions.text: Which of the following changes in hepatic metabolism best explains the increased incidence of ketoacidosis observed in type I diabetes?
questions.solution:
Justification:

  • In type-1 DM, there is deficiency of insulin which causes accelerated lipolysis (increase beta oxidation for energy) and more fatty acids are released into circulation.
  • Oxidation of these fatty acids increases the acetyl CoA pool.
  • Due to non-utilization of glucose, gluconeogenesis is enhanced causing less availability of oxaloacetate. So, acetyl co-A cannot enter in the TCA cycle and takes the alternate pathway for ketone body synthesis and causes ketoacidosis.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page Number-225.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presented to the ENT OPD. The mother is complaining that the child is suffering from hearing loss. The otoscopy picture is given in the image. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The otoscopy picture depicts a retracted tympanic membrane with a dull appearance and a fluid-filled middle ear space behind it. This clinical presentation is indicative of Otitis Media with Effusion (OME), also known as "glue ear". OME occurs when fluid accumulates in the middle ear without acute infection. It is common in young children and can lead to temporary hearing loss due to the restriction of tympanic membrane movement and interference with sound transmission to the inner ear.

Incorrect options:

Option B. Pneumotympanum - This condition refers to the presence of air in the middle ear cavity, but it is not consistent with the otoscopy image showing fluid-filled middle ear space.

Option C. Myringitis Bullosa - Myringitis Bullosa is characterized by the formation of bullae or blisters on the tympanic membrane. The image does not show any bullae or blisters.

Option D. Acute Suppurative Otitis Media - Acute Suppurative Otitis Media is characterized by the presence of pus in the middle ear due to a bacterial infection. The image does not show signs of active infection with pus formation.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Surgery by PL Dhingra, 7th Edition, Page Number-69.

choices.text: Multifocal IOL inserted in the capsular bag
Posterior chamber IOL inserted in the capsular bag
Posterior chamber IOL inserted in the sulcus

questions.text: Insertion of which one of the following intraocular lens (IOL) types usually requires a surgical iridectomy to be performed?
questions.solution:
• Insertion of an anterior chamber intraocular lens (IOL) usually requires a surgical iridectomy to prevent the risk of pupillary block glaucoma.


Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th Edition, Page Number 318-319.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after several episodes of vomiting and lethargy. His pediatrician has been concerned about his failure to thrive and possible hepatic failure along with recurrent episodes of vomiting and lethargy. After a careful history is taken, you observe that these episodes occur after ingestion of certain types of food, especially those high in fructose. His blood sugar was checked in the emergency department and was extremely low. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
Justification:

Fructose Intolerance:

  • It is an autosomal recessive inborn error of metabolism.
  • The hepatic fructose 1- phosphate aldolase B enzyme is defective; hence fructose 1- phosphate cannot be metabolized, and it will be accumulated.
  • Accumulation of fructose-1-phosphate will inhibit glycogen phosphorylase.
  • This leads to accumulation of glycogen in the liver and associated hypoglycemia
  • It does not cause difficulty as long as the patient does not consume any foods with fructose or sucrose.
  • This is seen when sucrose (containing fructose) is introduced in the diet of infants, usually around 6 months of age.
  • However, if chronically exposed to fructose-containing foods, infants and small children may have poor weight gain and abdominal cramping or vomiting.
  • Treatment: Avoid dietary fructose.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Chapter No:20, Page Number- 199

questions.text: This is an image of an important type of transport mechanism system. Identify the transport system.
questions.solution:
Justification:

  1. The co-transport system may either be a symport or an antiport.
    • In symport, the transporter carries two solutes in the same direction across the membrane, e.g. sodium dependent glucose transporter.
    • In an antiport system, the transporter carries two solutes or ions in opposite directions, e.g. sodium pump
  2. Uniport system carries a single solute across the membrane, e.g. glucose transporter in most of the cells.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Chapter No:40, Page Number: 476

choices.text: Topical corticosteroids and cycloplegic agents only

questions.text: Most patients presenting with acute, non-granulomatous anterior uveitis will require treatment with which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Most cases of acute anterior, non granulomatous, anterior uveitis respond well to topical corticosteroids and cycloplegic agents. In some cases, oral corticosteroids may be added.

Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th Edition, Page Number-432.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female is brought to the emergency department with a history of burns due to a gas cylinder blast in the kitchen. She has exudates all over her body surface. Her CBC report shows high hematocrit. Which type of shock is seen in the given case?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the patient's burn injury with exudates and a high hematocrit indicates a significant loss of fluid. Hypovolemic shock occurs when there is an inadequate amount of fluid in the vascular system. In the case of burns, especially those with exudates, rapid fluid loss leads to hypovolemia, necessitating prompt intervention.

Reference: Textbook of Practical Physiology by GK Pal, 2nd Edition, Page Number-869.

questions.text: All the following can lead to an increase in temperature of the body in the first two hours following death except:
questions.solution:
• Cholera, septicemia, and sunstroke lead to an increase in the body temperature in the first two hours following death. It is due to postmortem caloricity.
  • Postmortem caloricity is a condition in which the temperature of the body remains raised for the first two hours or so after death. This occurs:
    1. When the regulation of heat production has been severely disturbed before death, as in sunstroke, pontine hemorrhage and in some nervous disorders.
    2. When there has been a great increase in heat production in the muscles due to convulsions, as in tetanus and strychnine poisoning, or increased muscular activity as in cases of violent asphyxial deaths (struggle prior to death) etc.
    3. When there has been excessive bacterial activity, as in septicemic conditions, cholera and other fevers.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology by KS Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page Number-11.

questions.text: A 59-year-old female presented to the clinic with upper abdominal pain radiating to the back, fatigue, loss of appetite, nausea and anorexia. She also had considerable weight loss. On examination, she complaints of intense yellowish discolouration of her skin steadily increasing over the preceding 3 months. She also noted that her urine was dark yellow and stools were very pale. Her laboratory tests revealed a very high level of bilirubin, and also elevated urinary bilirubin. The liver transaminase enzymes were slightly elevated whereas alkaline phosphatase was markedly elevated. Abdominal ultrasonography revealed no evidence of gallstones. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Justification:

Ca head of the pancreas: It causes a type of obstructive jaundice. In Ca head pancreas, conjugated hyperbilirubinemia occurs due to blockage of the hepatic or common bile ducts. Bilirubin diglucuronide that cannot be excreted regurgitates into the hepatic veins and lymphatics, conjugated bilirubin appears in the blood and urine, and the stools typically are pale coloured.

Incorrect options-

  • Option A)Gilbert syndrome: It is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait. The defect is in the uptake of bilirubin by the liver. Bilirubin level is usually around 3 mg/dL, and patient is asymptomatic, except for the presence of mild jaundice
  • Option B) Type-1 Crigler Najjar Syndrome: The severe congenital jaundice (over 20 mg bilirubin per dL serum) and accompanying brain damage of type I Crigler Najjar syndrome reflects the complete absence of hepatic UDP-glucuronosyltransferase activity. Phototherapy reduces plasma bilirubin levels.
  • Ca head of the pancreas: It is a type of obstructive jaundice. In Ca head pancreas, conjugated hyperbilirubinemia occurs due to blockage of the hepatic or common bile ducts. Bilirubin diglucuronide that cannot be excreted regurgitates into the hepatic veins and lymphatics, conjugated bilirubin appears in the blood and urine, and the stools typically are a pale colour.

Option D)Infectious hepatitis: It is a type of hepatocellular jaundice which occurs due to any type of infective etiology. In this type of jaundice, ALT is markedly raised then ALP.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page Number-324.

questions.text:
Membranous nephropathy is associated with
A.HIV
B.SLE
C.CLL
D.Hepatitis B
Which of the following is not a cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism?
questions.solution:
Parathyroid adenoma causes primary hyperparathyroidism.

Secondary hyperparathyroidism occurs when the blood calcium level falls which stimulates the parathyroid glands to secrete more PTH in an attempt to increase the calcium levels. Eg: Vitamin D def

In CKD, FGF 23 increases which inhibits 1α hydroxylase which leads to vit D deficiency and secondary hyperparathyroidism.

In Li intake, the PTH secretion curve is shifted to the right. Higher Calcium levels are required to stimulate PTH secretion.

In primary hyperparathyroidism, there is autonomic growth of parathyroid glands. In secondary hyperparathyroidism, there is an adaptive response of the parathyroid glands and is typically reversible once the stimulus is removed.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of chronic alcohol abuse presents to the emergency department with altered mental status. He is disoriented, confused, and has difficulty walking. His family reports that he has been consuming excessive amounts of alcohol for several years, and has had a poor appetite recently. On examination, he has bilateral nystagmus and gait ataxia. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated mean corpuscular volume (MCV) and decreased serum thiamine levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Justification:

  • Wernicke's encephalopathy is a neurological disorder caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, commonly seen in individuals with chronic alcohol abuse due to poor nutrition and impaired thiamine absorption.
  • The classic triad of symptoms include confusion, oculomotor abnormalities (such as nystagmus), and gait ataxia.
  • These symptoms reflect the involvement of multiple brain regions, including the thalamus, hypothalamus, and cerebellum.
  • If left untreated, Wernicke's encephalopathy can progress to Korsakoff syndrome, characterized by severe memory impairment and confabulation.
  • Alcoholic liver disease may coexist with Wernicke's encephalopathy but is not the primary cause of the neurological symptoms described.
  • Cerebellar stroke would present with acute-onset focal neurological deficits, which are not consistent with the chronic, diffuse neurological symptoms seen in this patient.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page Number-541.

questions.text: Which of the following structures form the medial boundary of the femoral triangle?
questions.solution:
The femoral triangle is a subfascial space in the upper thigh, and its medial boundary is formed by the medial border of the adductor longus muscle. The lateral border is constituted by the medial border of the sartorius muscle. The base of the femoral triangle is formed by the inguinal ligament.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia: Human Anatomy, Volume-2, 8th Edition, Page Number-51.

choices.text: Decreased utilization of amino acid from gluconeogenesis
Leakage of amino acid from cells due to plasma membrane damage

questions.text: Increased alanine during prolonged starvation represents:
questions.solution:
• During prolonged starvation, there is increased gluconeogenesis. Alanine provided by muscle is one of the substrates for gluconeogenesis. This is called Cori's cycle or glucose-alanine cycle. Plasma level of alanine rises in prolonged starvation.

Remember:

  • In prolonged fasting, the plasma level of alanine rises.
  • In hyperammonemia, plasma level of glutamine rises.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page Number-187.

questions.text: The mother of a 1.5-month-old child comes with complaints that the child is vomiting frequently since the last 2 weeks and not gaining weight. The vomiting is non-bilious. On abdominal examination, there is a palpable oval mass. What is the definitive treatment for the condition?
questions.solution:
The symptoms described, including non-bilious vomiting, poor weight gain, and a palpable oval mass, are indicative of hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. The best treatment for hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is pyloromyotomy. Correction of alkalosis and NG tube feeding may be part of the initial management, but definitive treatment involves surgical intervention, such as pyloromyotomy.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 20th Edition, Page Number-1798.

questions.text: What is the Glasgow outcome score for severe disability?
questions.solution: Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page Number-369.

questions.text: The culture media for fungus is-
questions.solution:
The culture media used for the cultivation of fungi include Sabouraud's glucose agar,

Czapek-Dox medium, and corn meal agar. Sabouraud's medium is a widely used and suitable medium for the growth of various fungi. Understanding the appropriate culture media is crucial for the isolation and identification of fungal infections.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page Number-601.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient with a history of drug addiction presented with symptoms suggesting cocaine overdose. Which of the following features is not seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Cocaine blocks the uptake of NA and Adr into adrenergic nerve endings, resulting in higher concentrations of the transmitter around the receptors, leading to sympathomimetic effects such as local vasoconstriction, tachycardia, rise in BP, and mydriasis. Bradycardia is not a typical feature of cocaine overdose.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page Number-392.

questions.text: A HIV-infected 55-year-old man has a CD4+ count of 45 cells/mm3. He also complains of weight loss, night sweats, and fever. On examination, hepatosplenomegaly is noted. Examination of his BAL fluid shows macrophages filled with acid-fast organisms. Which is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
In HIV-positive patients, bacterial and tubercular infections are more likely at higher CD4+ counts (>200 cells/mm3). Pneumocystis pneumonia usually strikes at CD4+ counts less than 200 cells/mm3, while CMV, fungal, and Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare complex infections are uncommon until the disease is very advanced (CD4+ counts less than 50 cells/mm3).

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page Number-7

questions.text: Identify the type of reaction given in the image below.
questions.solution:
Justification:

Transamination

  • Definition - Transfer of alpha amino group from one amino acid to a keto acid to form another pair of amino acid and keto acid.
  • Amino group from amino acids are concentrated in the form of glutamate because only glutamate can undergo oxidative deamination to a significant amount thereby releasing ammonia that enters into the urea cycle.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page Number-282.

choices.text: 60 mg Iron + 500 mcg Folic acid
100 mg Iron + 500 mcg Folic acid
60 mg Iron + 100 mcg Folic acid
100 mg Iron + 100 mcg Folic acid

questions.text: Under the MCH programme, what is the composition of iron and folic acid tablets to be given daily to a mother?
questions.solution:
Option (A): 60 mg Iron + 500 mcg Folic acid (Correct Answer):

  • Under the Maternal and Child Health (MCH) programme, Iron and Folic acid supplementation is provided to pregnant women to prevent iron deficiency anemia and neural tube defects in the fetus.
  • The recommended dosage for daily iron supplementation during pregnancy is typically 60 mg of elemental iron, along with 500 mcg (micrograms) of folic acid.
  • This combination is effective in meeting the increased iron and folic acid requirements of pregnant women and supporting the healthy development of the fetus.

Incorrect options:

Option B): 100 mg Iron + 500 mcg folic acid:

  • Providing 100 mg of elemental iron daily during pregnancy may lead to excessive iron intake and potential adverse effects, such as constipation, nausea, and gastrointestinal discomfort.
  • The standard dosage of iron supplementation during pregnancy is usually lower, around 60 mg per day, to balance the need for iron with the risk of side effects.
  • While the folic acid dosage in this option is correct, the iron dosage is higher than the recommended amount for routine supplementation during pregnancy.

Option C): 60 mg Iron + 100 mcg Folic acid:

  • This option provides an insufficient dosage of folic acid for pregnant women. The recommended daily intake of folic acid during pregnancy is 400 to 800 mcg to reduce the risk of neural tube defects in the fetus.
  • Additionally, the iron dosage of 60 mg is appropriate, but the inadequate folic acid content makes this option unsuitable for maternal supplementation during pregnancy.

Option D): 100 mg Iron + 100 mcg Folic acid:

  • Similar to option B, providing 100 mg of elemental iron daily may result in excessive iron intake and potential adverse effects, without offering additional benefits in terms of iron status or fetal development.
  • Additionally, the folic acid dosage of only 100 mcg is significantly lower than the recommended amount for pregnant women and may not provide adequate protection against neural tube defects in the fetus.

In summary, option A is the correct answer as it provides the appropriate combination of 60 mg iron and 500 mcg folic acid, meeting the recommended daily requirements for iron and folic acid supplementation during pregnancy. Options (b), (c), and (d) either provide excessive or insufficient dosages of iron and/or folic acid, making them inappropriate choices for maternal supplementation under the MCH program.

choices.text: Left side loss of proprioception and 2-point discrimination below the level of the lesion
Left side loss of pain and temperature sensation below the level of the lesion
Right side loss of pain and temperature sensation below the level of the lesion
Left side motor loss, muscle paralysis, and spasticity below the level of the lesion

questions.text: A man was rushed to the hospital after a bullet injury. On investigation, there was an injury to the left side of the hemi section of the spinal cord at the L4 level. Which among the following is FALSE according to the findings?
questions.solution:
Brown-Sequard Syndrome occurs in hemisection of the spinal cord, leading to ipsilateral loss of proprioception and 2-point discrimination, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation. Therefore, the statement about the right side loss of pain and temperature sensation below the level of the lesion is accurate, not false.

Reference: Textbook of Practical Physiology by GK Pal, 2nd Edition, Page Number-1038.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is falsely matched?
questions.solution:
• Positive and negative vital reactions are seen only in antemortem wounds, and in postmortem wounds, there is no vital reaction.

The vital reactions of a wound are of two types:

  • In the immediate vicinity of a wound edge, a central or superficial zone, 0.2 – 0.5mm deep shows decreasing enzyme activity, also known as the negative vital reaction.
  • Surrounding the central area, a peripheral zone 0.1 – 0.3mm deep, exhibits an increase in enzyme activity, also known as positive vital reaction.
  • This is demonstrable as early as one hour after wounding and becomes even more apparent later.
  • These reactions are not seen in a postmortem wound.

Reference: Textbook of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology by Anil Aggrawal, Page Number-229.

questions.text: All of the following are the causes of a high anion gap metabolic acidosis except-
questions.solution:
High anion gap metabolic acidosis is a type of metabolic acidosis characterized by an elevated anion gap in the blood. The anion gap is calculated by subtracting the measured concentrations of chloride and bicarbonate ions from the concentration of sodium ions in the blood.

Causes of high anion gap metabolic acidosis include:

  1. Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA): In DKA, there is an accumulation of ketone bodies, leading to an increase in the anion gap.
  2. Renal tubular acidosis (RTA): This is an incorrect option. Renal tubular acidosis is typically associated with a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis. It is a disorder of renal acid-base regulation.
  3. Starvation: In prolonged fasting or starvation, there can be an increase in the production of ketone bodies, leading to a high anion gap metabolic acidosis.
  4. Acute renal failure: In acute renal failure, there can be a buildup of metabolic acids in the blood, contributing to a high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Therefore, the correct answer is B. Renal tubular acidosis, as it is not typically associated with a high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman who recently underwent a left mastectomy and axillary dissection for breast cancer now presents to her physician with a chief complaint that she feels like her shoulder blade sticks out sometimes. She denies any pain. This patient's injured nerve originates at which spinal levels?
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms of shoulder blade sticking out, known as winging, indicate damage to the long thoracic nerve. This nerve, responsible for serratus anterior muscle innervation, originates from the brachial plexus at C5, C6, and C7. Injury during mastectomy can lead to this characteristic presentation.

Reference: Campbell’s Operative Orthopaedics, 13th Edition, Page Number-1475.

choices.text: Menarche > growth spurt beginning > thelarche > pubarche
Growth spurt beginning > thelarche > menarche > pubarche
Menarche > thelarche > growth spurt beginning > pubarche
Growth spurt beginning > thelarche > pubarche > menarche

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding changes in puberty?
questions.solution:
• First change in puberty is the beginning of growth spurt.
  • It is followed by breast bud development, pubic and axillary hair development, and menses.

questions.text: Most common congenital heart valve defect is?
questions.solution:
BICUSPID AORTIC VALVE DISEASE

  • Most common congenital heart valve defect.
  • Males are more commonly affected.
  • Pattern of inheritance is autosomal dominant.
  • Gene mutations implicated are: NOTCH1, Endothelial nitric oxide synthase
  • Most common cause of isolated aortic stenosis in adults
  • Higher incidence of ascending aortic aneurysm
  • Higher incidence of aortic dissection

questions.text: A 50-year-old building contractor complains of dyspnea and mild cough. Initially, he had dyspnea on exertion, which progressed to dyspnea even at rest. His chest X-ray shows calcified pleural plaques and fibrosis. An image of his lung biopsy is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows an asbestos body, revealing the typical beading and knobbed ends. In patients with asbestosis, dyspnea is usually the first manifestation, provoked by exertion initially, later presented even at rest as the disease progresses. Chest X-ray studies reveal irregular linear densities, particularly in both lower lobes.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page Number-695.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female married for 2 years visits an infertility clinic. She was put on HMG. On treatment, she developed dyspnea and abdominal pain. Her USG report shows the following image. What is the condition called?
questions.solution:
• Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome-Its symptoms are the result of ovarian enlargement and fragility, extravascular fluid accumulation, and intravascular volume depletion.
  • Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), whose expression in granulosa cells and serum is augmented by hCG, has been implicated in the pathogenesis of this disease.
  • Two distinct patterns of OHSS onset have been Early OHSS occurs 3 to 7 days following the hCG trigger and is associated with the administration of exogenous hCG.
  • Late onset disease occurs 9 days after the hCG trigger; it is the result of endogenous hCG secretion from the pregnancy and tends to be more severe with multiple gestation.

questions.text: From the general examination finding of this 40-year-old female admitted in the medicine ward, what is the likely nutrient deficiency that the patient is having?
questions.solution: The patient in question is having perifollicular hemorrhages and corkscrew shaped hair suggestive of Scurvy (Vitamin C deficiency).

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy complains of dyspnea. Wheezing is also observed. On examination of his sputum, Charcot Leyden crystals and Curschmann's spirals are seen. Which of the following histologic findings are not seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Characteristic histologic findings of asthma, called airway remodeling, include thickening of the airway wall, sub-basement membrane fibrosis, increased vascularity, increased size of submucosal glands, and hypertrophy and/or hyperplasia of bronchial wall muscle.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page Number-686.

choices.text: Serum estrogen (E2) level is 200 pg/ml per dominant follicle

questions.text: Ovulation trigger can be given when:
questions.solution:
• Ovulation triggering with hCG is recommended when 1-2 follicles are 16 to 18 mm in diameter and the E2 level per dominant follicle is 150-300 pg/ml.
  • Ovulation is expected 24 to 48 hours after the hCG trigger.

questions.text: The following is the ECG of a patient done as a part of routine work up before a major surgery. Seeing the abnormality, a medicine consultation is done to comment on this ECG. What is the likely explanation the medicine consultant has for the ECG finding?
questions.solution: The ECG finding is that of the Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB). LBBB may be a finding in ischemic heart disease, cardiomyopathy and hypertensive heart disease.

questions.text: A 70-year-old smoker has been complaining of multifocal bony pains for 6 months. On examination, he has firm, non-tender right cervical lymphadenitis (Virchow node). His serum calcium level is raised. His chest X-ray shows a 6 cm mass in the right lung, invading the mediastinum. An image of a biopsy from his lung shows keratinization and necrosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Squamous cell carcinoma in the lung is associated with hypercalcemia as a systemic effect. A diagnosis of SCC can be confirmed when a minimum of 10% of the tumor bulk of resected samples exhibits transformation features such as keratinization or intracellular bridges. Symptoms can include cough, chest pain, shortness of breath, blood in sputum, wheezing, hoarseness, recurring chest infections (including bronchitis and pneumonia), weight loss, and loss of appetite and fatigue.

Reference: Rosai and Ackerman’s Surgical Pathology, 11th Edition, Page Number 400, 406.

questions.text: Identify the instrument used to insufflate the peritoneal cavity.
questions.solution: The instrument used to insufflate the peritoneal cavity is Veress needle as shown in the image.

questions.text: Pityriasis versicolor is caused by:
questions.solution:
Pityriasis versicolor, also known as Tinea versicolor, is caused by the non-dermatophyte dimorphic fungus Malassezia furfur. This chronic superficial fungal infection leads to hypopigmentation or hyperpigmentation of the skin. Understanding the causative agents of different skin conditions is crucial for accurate diagnosis and treatment.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page Number-603.

choices.text: Ventral primary rami of L4, L5, S1, S2
Ventral primary rami of L5, S1, S2, S3
Dorsal primary rami of L4, L5, S1, S2
Dorsal primary rami of L5, S1, S2, S3

questions.text: What is the root value of the nerve supplying the skin adjoining the cleft between the first and second toes?
questions.solution:
The nerve supplying the skin adjoining the cleft between the first and second toes is the deep peroneal nerve, which is one of the two terminal branches of the common peroneal nerve. Its root value includes the ventral primary rami of L4, L5, S1, and S2 segments of the spinal cord.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia: Human Anatomy, Volume-2, 8th Edition, Page Number 108,115.

questions.text: A 3-day-old baby is brought by the mother with complaints that the child has not passed stools since birth. The abdomen is distended, and he has stopped taking feeds since morning. An NG tube can be passed per annum that shows stool staining. You suspect Hirschsprung disease in the child. Which is the best diagnostic evaluation?
questions.solution:
In a case of suspected Hirschsprung disease, the gold standard diagnostic evaluation is a rectal biopsy. Hirschsprung disease involves the absence of ganglion cells in the distal part of the colon, leading to functional obstruction. Rectal biopsy is crucial for confirming the diagnosis by examining the presence or absence of ganglion cells.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 20th Edition, Page Number-1811

questions.text: What is the gold standard investigation in a case of nodular goitre?
questions.solution:
• Thyroid function should be assessed to exclude mild hyperthyroidism, and the presence of circulating thyroid antibodies tested to differentiate from autoimmune thyroiditis.
  • Ultrasound is the gold standard assessment, when undertaken by a suitably trained and experienced operator.
  • FNAC is only required for a nodule within the goitre that demonstrates ultrasonic features of concern. This may or may not be the largest 'dominant' nodule.
  • The biopsy should be performed under ultrasonic guidance to ensure the correct nodule is sampled.
  • If there are swallowing or breathing symptoms, then a CT scan of the thoracic inlet is the best modality to assess tracheal or esophageal compression.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page Number-857.

questions.text: Which of the following monoclonal antibodies is approved for hereditary angioneurotic edema?
questions.solution:
Lanadelumab is a fully human IgG1/kappa light chain monoclonal antibody approved for the long-term prophylaxis of hereditary angioedema in patients 12 years and older. It rapidly inhibits active plasma kallikrein, preventing HMW kininogen cleavage and generation of bradykinin.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th Edition, Page Number-870.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman is diagnosed with chronic gastritis. Which of the following complications may occur?
questions.solution:
Chronic gastritis may lead to complications such as mucosal atrophy, intestinal metaplasia, dysplasia, and even gastritis cystica.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page Number-771.

questions.text: What is the average weight gain during pregnancy in a poor Indian woman?
questions.solution:
Option C) : 6.5 kg (Correct answer)

  • The average weight gain during pregnancy for a poor Indian woman is typically around 6.5 kilograms.
  • This estimation considers various factors such as the starting weight of the woman, her nutritional status, and her socio- economic background.
  • In many cases, women from lower socio- economic backgrounds may experience lower weight gain during pregnancy due to factors such as limited access to nutritious food, inadequate prenatal care, and higher prevalence of undernutrition.

Incorrect options:

Option A): 12 kg:

  • A weight gain of 12 kilograms during pregnancy is relatively high, especially for a poor Indian woman who may face challenges related to food insecurity and limited access to healthcare.
  • While some women may indeed gain more weight during pregnancy, particularly if they were underweight before conception, 12 kilograms would be considered excessive for the average poor Indian woman.

Option B): 10 kg:

  • Similar to option A, a weight gain of 10 kilograms during pregnancy is relatively high and may not accurately reflect the typical experience of poor Indian women.
  • While some variation in weight gain is expected based on individual factors, 10 kilograms would be considered on the higher end of the spectrum for this population.

Option D): 2.5 kg:

  • A weight gain of only 2.5 kilograms during pregnancy would be considered insufficient and potentially indicative of maternal undernutrition or other health concerns.
  • Poor Indian women are at higher risk of inadequate weight gain during pregnancy due to factors such as poverty, limited access to healthcare, and food insecurity. However, 2.5 kilograms would be too low to represent the average weight gain for this population.

In summary, option C) (6.5 kg) is the most accurate representation of the average weight gain during pregnancy for poor Indian women. Other options either overestimate or underestimate the typical weight gain for this population, making them less accurate choices.

questions.text: After hemoglobin catabolism, bilirubin is catabolized. It is a 3-step metabolism process i.e. uptake, conjugation, and excretion. Out of this, which is the rate-limiting step in hepatic bilirubin metabolism?
questions.solution:
The rate-limiting step in hepatic bilirubin metabolism is excretion. After uptake and conjugation, bilirubin is excreted into the intestine. This process involves enterohepatic circulation and conversion to urobilinogen. Impaired excretion can lead to jaundice and other associated complications.

Reference: Textbook of Practical Physiology by GK Pal, 2nd Edition, Page Number-101.

questions.text: A magistrate can pass an order for admission of a neglected, mentally ill person for assessment for a maximum period of-
questions.solution:
Section 102 of Mental Health Care Act 2017:

(1) When any person with mental illness or who may have a mental illness appears or is brought before a Magistrate, the Magistrate may, order in writing––

  1. That the person is conveyed to a public mental health establishment for assessment and treatment, if necessary and the mental health establishment shall deal with such person in accordance with the provisions of the Act; or
  2. To authorise the admission of the person with mental illness in a mental health establishment for such a period not exceeding ten days to enable the medical officer or mental health professional in charge of the mental health establishment to carry out an assessment of the person and to plan for necessary treatment, if any.

(2) On completion of the period of assessment, the medical officer or mental health professional in charge of the mental health establishment shall submit a report to the Magistrate and the person shall be dealt with in accordance with the provisions of this Act

Reference: Mental Health Care Act, 2017.

questions.text: A 54-year-old female presented with cough and dyspnea of 4 years duration. She has a history of anterior uveitis. The physician also noticed the following general examination finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Skin involvement is eventually identified in over a one-third of patients with sarcoidosis. The classic cutaneous lesions include erythema nodosum, maculopapular lesions, hyper- and hypopigmentation, keloid formation, and subcutaneous nodules. A specific complex of involvement of the bridge of the nose, the area beneath the eyes, and the cheeks is referred to as lupus pernio and is diagnostic for a chronic form of sarcoidosis.

questions.text: The following general examination findings were noticed in a 40-year-old male who presented to the OPD. What is the likely enzymatic defect ?
questions.solution: Ochronosis is a rare disorder which manifests as a bluish-black discoloration of the skin and mucosa. It occurs due to deficiency of an enzyme homogentisic acid oxidase.

questions.text: What would a fracture of the ulna with lateral dislocation of the radial head be classified as?
questions.solution:
Bado's classification is used for Monteggia fracture dislocations. In this case, Bado type III involves posterolateral dislocation of the radial head. Understanding such classifications is essential for accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment planning in orthopaedics.

Reference: Rockwood and Green's Fractures in Adults, 8th Edition, Page Number-3602.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female with primary infertility has acanthosis nigricans and hirsutism. Her USG shows PCOD. What is the best drug for ovulation induction?
questions.solution:
This is a case of polycystic ovarian disease(PCOD).

  • DOC for ovulation induction in a PCOD patient: letrozole with metformin > clomiphene + metformin

questions.text: Which of the following cancers cannot be prevented by Gardasil?
questions.solution:
Cervical, vulval, anorectal, oropharyngeal, head and neck cancer, warts by HPV 6,11 can be prevented by Gardasil and Gardasil 9.

It is given at the age of 9-45 years.

2nd dose in 9-14 years: 0 and 6-12 months

3rd dose at 15-45 years: 0,2,6 months

0.5 ml IM injection

questions.text: The earliest immunoglobulin to be synthesized by the fetus is-
questions.solution:
IgM is the earliest immunoglobulin class to be synthesized by the fetus, starting at around 20 weeks. It is not transported across the placenta, and its presence in the fetus or newborn indicates recent infection. IgM is crucial in the primary antibody response and is associated with early immune reactions.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page Number-99

questions.text: The Brodie's bursa lies deep to which of the following muscles?
questions.solution:
Brodie's bursa is a bursa located deep to the popliteus muscle in the knee joint. This bursa can also be found deep to the medial head of the gastrocnemius and may communicate with the cavity of the knee joint.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia: Human Anatomy, Volume-2, 8th Edition, Page Number-127.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 18 weeks of gestation has a uterus size of 16 weeks on examination. USG shows oligohydramnios. Which of the following fetal causes is likely in this case?
questions.solution:
Oligohydramnios at 18 weeks of gestation with a uterus size smaller than expected suggests a fetal cause. Renal agenesis, where there is a lack of kidney development, can lead to decreased amniotic fluid (oligohydramnios). Anencephaly is associated with polyhydramnios, not oligohydramnios. Twin gestation is generally not associated with decreased amniotic fluid.

Reference: Cloherty and Stark’s Manual of Neonatal Care, 2nd SA Edition, Page Number-385.

questions.text: Which group of lymph nodes in the breast are included in the external mammary group?
questions.solution:
Six axillary lymph node groups are recognized by surgeons:

  • Axillary Vein Group (Lateral Group):
    • Location: Medial or posterior to the axillary vein.
    • Number: Four to six lymph nodes.
    • Function: Receives most lymph drainage from the upper extremity.
  • External Mammary Group (Anterior or Pectoral Group):
    • Location: Along the lower border of the pectoralis minor muscle, contiguous with lateral thoracic vessels.
    • Number: Five to six lymph nodes.
    • Function: Receives most lymph drainage from the lateral aspect of the breast.
  • Scapular Group (Posterior or Subscapular):
    • Location: Along the posterior wall of the axilla, at the lateral border of the scapula, contiguous with subscapular vessels.
    • Number: Five to seven lymph nodes.
    • Function: Receives lymph drainage primarily from the lower posterior neck, posterior trunk, and posterior shoulder.
  • Central Group:
    • Location: Embedded in the fat of the axilla, immediately posterior to the pectoralis minor muscle.
    • Number: Three or four sets of lymph nodes.
    • Function: Receives lymph drainage from the axillary vein, external mammary, and scapular groups of lymph nodes, and directly from the breast.
  • Subclavicular Group (Apical):
    • Location: Posterior and superior to the upper border of the pectoralis minor muscle.
    • Number: Six to twelve sets of lymph nodes.
    • Function: Receives lymph drainage from all other groups of axillary lymph nodes.
  • Interpectoral Group:
    • Description: Lymph nodes in this group pass directly into the central and subclavicular groups.

These axillary lymph node groups play a crucial role in draining lymphatic fluid from different regions of the breast and upper extremity, contributing to the overall lymphatic system's function in the chest and arm area.

Reference: Schwartz Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page Number-546.

questions.text: Which of the following monoclonal antibodies is approved for use in severe eosinophilic asthma?
questions.solution:
Mepolizumab is an anti-interleukin-5 (anti-IL-5) monoclonal antibody used in the treatment of severe eosinophilic asthma. It specifically targets IL-5, a cytokine involved in eosinophil maturation and activation. Severe eosinophilic asthma is characterized by persistent elevated eosinophil levels, contributing to asthma exacerbations. Mepolizumab helps reduce eosinophilic inflammation, leading to improved asthma control. Administered subcutaneously every 4 weeks, it has demonstrated efficacy in reducing exacerbations and enhancing overall quality of life in clinical trials.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th Edition, Page Number-890.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child has a history of recurrent infections and bleeding gums. On investigations, the patient had pancytopenia and the peripheral smear showed macrocytes. The bone marrow biopsy showed no megakaryocytes but had fat filled marrow. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Fat filled marrow, without megakaryocytes is suggestive of aplastic anemia.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page Number-1040.

questions.text: How is the diagnostic accuracy of a test determined?
questions.solution:
The diagnostic accuracy of a test refers to its ability to correctly classify individuals as either having or not having a particular disease or condition. While prevalence, sensitivity, and specificity are important factors in evaluating the performance of a diagnostic test, none of them directly determine the overall diagnostic accuracy. Instead, predictive accuracy, which encompasses both sensitivity and specificity, provides a comprehensive measure of a test's ability to correctly classify individuals.

Predictive accuracy, also known as diagnostic accuracy or diagnostic efficiency, considers both sensitivity and specificity to provide a comprehensive measure of a test's ability to correctly classify individuals as either having or not having the disease. Predictive accuracy takes into account both true positives and true negatives relative to all individuals tested, regardless of disease prevalence. It reflects the overall performance of the test in accurately diagnosing individuals and is therefore the most appropriate measure for determining the diagnostic accuracy of a test.

Incorrect options:

Option A) Prevalence: Prevalence refers to the proportion of individuals in a population who have a particular disease or condition at a specific point in time. While prevalence is an essential epidemiological measure, it does not directly determine the diagnostic accuracy of a test. Prevalence influences the pre-test probability of disease in the population, which can affect the positive and negative predictive values of the test but does not determine its overall diagnostic accuracy.

Option B) Sensitivity: Sensitivity measures the proportion of individuals with the disease who test positive on the diagnostic test (true positives). Sensitivity indicates the test's ability to correctly identify individuals who have the disease among all individuals who truly have the disease. While sensitivity is crucial for ruling in individuals who have the disease, it alone does not determine the overall diagnostic accuracy.

Option C) Specificity: Specificity measures the proportion of individuals without the disease who test negative on the diagnostic test (true negatives). Specificity indicates the test's ability to correctly identify individuals who do not have the disease among all individuals who truly do not have the disease. Similar to sensitivity, specificity is essential for ruling out individuals who do not have the disease but does not determine the overall diagnostic accuracy.

In summary, while prevalence, sensitivity, and specificity are important components in evaluating a diagnostic test's performance, predictive accuracy provides a more comprehensive measure of the test's overall ability to correctly classify individuals as having or not having the disease. Therefore, option d, predictive accuracy, is the most appropriate answer for determining the diagnostic accuracy of a test.

questions.text: In India, the age under which a boy is considered incapable of committing rape is-
questions.solution:
In India, there is no age limit under which a boy is considered incapable of committing rape. As per the definition of rape, rape is not only insertion of penis into vagina, but it also an offence of rape, if a child inserts finger or any object into the vagina. But as per Sec. 82 IPC, nothing is an offence which is done by a child under seven years of age.

Sec. 375 IPC

A man is said to commit "rape" if he

  • penetrates his penis, to any extent, into the vagina, mouth, urethra or anus of a woman or makes her to do so with him or any other person; or
  • inserts, to any extent, any object or a part of the body, not being the penis, into the vagina, the urethra or anus of a woman or makes her to do so with him or any other person; or
  • manipulates any part of the body of a woman so as to cause penetration into the vagina, urethra, anus or any part of body of such woman or makes her to do so with him or any other person; or
  • applies his mouth to the vagina, anus, urethra of a woman or makes her to do so with him or any other person, under the circumstances falling under any of the following seven descriptions:
    1. Against her will.
    2. Without her consent.
    3. With her consent, when her consent has been obtained by putting her or any person in whom she is interested in fear of death or hurt.
    4. With her consent, when a woman believes he is another man to whom she is lawfully married.
    5. With her consent, when she is unable to understand the nature and consequences of that to which she gives consent.
    6. With or without her consent when she is under 18 years of age; or
    7. When she is unable to communicate consent.

Provided that a woman who does not physically resist the act of penetration shall not by the reason only of that fact, be regarded as consenting to the sexual activity.

Exception 1 - A medical procedure or intervention shall not constitute rape.

Exception 2 - Sexual intercourse or sexual acts by a man with his own wife, the wife not being under 15 years of age, is not rape.

The Supreme Court on October 11, 2017, criminalized sex between a man and his underaged wife, provided a complaint is filed within a year.

The court said the exception in the rape law that allowed a man to have sex with his minor wife aged between 15 and 18 was arbitrary and violated the Constitution. It also said Exception 2 in Section 375 of the Indian Penal Code was contrary to the philosophy of other statutes and violated the bodily integrity of a girl child.

Reference: Criminal Law (Amendment) Act, 2013. In the Supreme court of India, Civil original jurisdiction, Writ petition (civil) No. 382 of 2013.

questions.solution: Dyskeratosis congenita is an inherited bone marrow failure syndrome characterized clinically by the triad of abnormal nails, reticular skin pigmentation, and oral leukoplakia, and is associated with very high risk of developing aplastic anemia, myelodysplastic syndrome, leukemia, and solid tumors. Some features typically appear in childhood but pulmonary fibrosis and liver cirrhosis typically present in adulthood. The image in the question shows the characteristic triad.

questions.text: A 56-year-old postmenopausal patient has acute abdominal pain. Her uterus size is 12 weeks by per vaginal examination. She had no complaints before this. Her USG was normal 5 months ago. What is the diagnosis of the patient?
questions.solution: Postmenopausal patient + acute abdominal pain + rapid growth in uterus size (>6 weeks size in 1 year) is diagnostic of uterine sarcoma.

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman presents with an inability to walk after a fall at her home yesterday. On physical examination, the left leg is shorter than the right leg. The injured extremity is in abduction and is slightly externally rotated. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's age, inability to walk, and characteristic findings of a shorter, externally rotated, and abducted leg strongly suggests a hip fracture. In the elderly, femoral neck fractures are common and can lead to significant morbidity and mortality.

Reference: Rockwood and Green’s Fractures in Adults, 9th Edition, Page Number-3602.

questions.text: There are many special microscopes used in the field of microbiology. All have special uses. Dark ground microscopy is used to see-
questions.solution:
Dark ground (dark field) microscopy is employed to visualize structures like flagella and spirochetes. The technique involves a special condenser that prevents direct illumination of the specimen, making certain structures more visible. Understanding the applications of different microscopy techniques is vital for microbiological investigations.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page Number-11.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of renal artery stenosis in young adults in western countries ?
questions.solution:
FIBROMUSCULAR DYSPLASIA

  • Most common cause of renal artery stenosis in young adults in Western countries.
  • More common in females. Female: Male prevalence is 8:1.
  • Most common histological variant of Fibromuscular dysplasia is Medial fibroplasia.
  • Lesions are frequently bilateral.
  • In contrast to atherosclerotic renovascular disease (which affects origin of renal artery frequently), fibromuscular dysplasia tends to affect more distal portions of the renal artery.
  • The iliac arteries are the limb arteries most likely to be affected by fibromuscular dysplasia.
  • It is identified angiographically by a "string of beads" appearance (shown in image) caused by thickened fibromuscular ridges contiguous with thin, less involved portions of the arterial wall.

questions.text: Tocilizumab is FDA approved in the treatment of -
questions.solution: Tocilizumab (anti-IL-6 receptor) was FDA approved for this indication. It is used adjunctively too. The side effect profile of tocilizumab includes leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, transaminase elevation, and hyperlipidemia.

questions.text: The transpyloric plane passes through all the following structures except-
questions.solution:
The transpyloric plane is an imaginary transverse plane in anatomical descriptions. It passes through various structures including the pylorus of the stomach, hilum of the kidneys, neck of the pancreas, and origin of the coeliac artery. However, it does not pass through the neck of the gallbladder.


Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia: Human Anatomy, Volume-2, 8th Edition, Page Number-234.

questions.text: Which is the typical special histologic type seen in triple-negative breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Triple-negative breast cancers often exhibit the medullary histologic type. Molecular subtypes of invasive breast cancer include luminal A, luminal B, HER2-enriched, and basal-like (triple-negative), with the medullary subtype being a variant of the basal-like type.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page Number-1050.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman noted increasing fullness in her neck for the past 8 months. On physical examination, her thyroid gland is diffusely, asymmetrically enlarged, and nodular. She undergoes thyroidectomy. Gross examination of the thyroid shows a multicentric thyroid neoplasm; microscopically, the neoplasm is composed of polygonal to spindle-shaped cells forming nests and trabeculae. There is a prominent, pink hyaline stroma that stains positively with Congo red. Electron microscopy shows varying numbers of intracytoplasmic, membrane-bound, electron-dense granules. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The histologic features described, including polygonal to spindle- shaped cells forming nests and trabeculae, Congo red-positive pink hyaline stroma, and intracytoplasmic electron-dense granules, are consistent with medullary thyroid carcinoma.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page Number 1088-1092.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male patient was operated for prostate carcinoma, and during surgery, local metastasis foci were noted. Which of the following drugs should be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Leuprolide, a long-acting GnRH agonist, is indicated in the palliative treatment of carcinoma prostate. It acts by suppressing gonadotropin secretion, leading to decreased testosterone levels. In prostate carcinoma, which is often hormone-sensitive, reducing testosterone levels can slow tumor growth and alleviate symptoms. Leuprolide is administered subcutaneously or intramuscularly daily or as a depot injection, once a month.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page Number-265.

questions.text: Repair of the peripheral one third of the meniscus is sometimes possible because it has which of the following characteristics?
questions.solution:
The outer one third of the meniscus is well vascularized, contributing to its potential for repair. This characteristic is crucial for healing after injury or surgery, as a good blood supply enhances tissue regeneration and recovery.

Reference: Orthopaedic Basic Science: Biology and Biomechanics of the Musculoskeletal System, Buckwalter JA, Einhorn TA, Simon SR (eds), Page Number 532-545.
