questions.text: Which of these is an example of multiphasic screening?
questions.solution:
Multiphasic screening refers to the process of conducting multiple screening tests or evaluations as part of a comprehensive health assessment. This approach allows for the detection of various diseases or risk factors in a systematic manner.

Option B) Annual health check-ups: This option involves regular comprehensive health assessments conducted annually. During these check-ups, various screening tests and evaluations may be performed to assess overall health, detect diseases, and identify risk factors. Multiphasic screening can be achieved through the inclusion of multiple tests or assessments as part of these check-ups, making option b the correct choice.

Incorrect options:

Option A) Chest X-ray for TB in a large population: This option involves a single screening test (chest X-ray) aimed at detecting tuberculosis in a large population. While it may be part of a screening program, it does not involve multiple phases or different types of screening tests.

Option C) Pap smear in old females: Pap smear, also known as cervical cytology, is a specific screening test aimed at detecting cervical cancer or precancerous changes in the cervix. While it is an important screening test for older females, it does not encompass the multiphasic approach of conducting multiple screening tests or evaluations.

Option D) Mammography in all young females: Mammography is a specific screening test for breast cancer, typically recommended for females starting at a certain age (usually around 40 or 50 years old) or based on individual risk factors. Similar to option C, mammography focuses on a single screening test for a specific disease rather than a multiphasic approach.

Therefore, option B, annual health check-ups, is the example of multiphasic screening because it involves conducting multiple screening tests and evaluations as part of a comprehensive health assessment on a regular basis.

Multiphasic screening involves conducting multiple screening tests or examinations as part of a comprehensive health assessment.

questions.text: According to WHO, what is the minimum number of ANC visits?
questions.solution:
ANTENATAL VISITS

  • Ideallythe mother should attend the antenatal clinic once a month during the first 7 months; twice a month, during the next month; and thereafter, once a week, if everything is normal. Hence, ideally there should be 13-14 antenatal visits.
  • A high proportion of mothers in India are from lower socio-economic groups, and many of them are working Attendance at the antenatal clinic may mean loss of daily wages.
  • Consequently,it is difficult for them to attend the antenatal clinic so In these cases, a minimum of 4 visits covering the entire period of pregnancy should be the target. The suggested schedule is as follows :
    1. 1stvisit : Within 12 weeks, preferably as soon as the pregnancy is suspected, for registration of pregnancy and first antenatal check-up.
    2. 2ndvisit: Between 14 and 26
    3. 3rdvisit: Between 28 and 34
    4. 4thvisit: Between 36 weeks and
  • It is advisable for the woman to visit medical officer at the PHC for an antenatal check-up during the period of 28-34 weeks (3rd visit).
  • Besidesthis, she may be advised to avail investigation facilities at the nearest PHC/CHC/FRU.
  • Registrationof pregnancy within 12 weeks is the primary responsibility of the
  • Opportunitiessuch as Village Health Nutrition Day should be availed to ensure early registration of pregnancy and antenatal check-up.
  • WHO RECOMMENDATION: Minimum of 8 antenatal

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition

questions.text: An MBBS student went for his medicine posting for the first time. He saw a patient with low blood pressure, feeling dizzy, confused, and with diarrhea, nausea, and vomiting. A PG student told him this was a case of septic shock. Septic shock is due to:
questions.solution:
Septic shock is primarily due to the endotoxin (lipopolysaccharide) of gram-negative bacteria. Lipopolysaccharide triggers an inflammatory response leading to the characteristic symptoms of septic shock. Understanding the molecular basis of different shock conditions is crucial for appropriate management.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page Number 80-83

questions.text: Cremasteric fascia is derived from which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
The cremasteric fascia is made up of muscle loops constituting the cremaster muscle and the intervening areolar tissue. It is derived from the internal oblique muscle and covers the spermatic cord below the level of these muscles.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia: Human Anatomy, Volume-2, 8th Edition, Page Number 250,260.

questions.text: A child comes with features of a coarse face, hypercalcemia, and a cardiac murmur of aortic stenosis. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The presentation of a child with a coarse face, hypercalcemia, and cardiac murmur of aortic stenosis is indicative of Williams syndrome. Williams syndrome is characterized by cardiovascular abnormalities, including supravalvular aortic stenosis. Other features may include a unique facial appearance, developmental delays, and hypercalcemia.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 20th Edition, Page Number-2203.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of pain and swelling to the distal interphalangeal joints of the right index and left ring fingers and diffuse swelling and pain of the right great toe. He has had an intermittent rash to the scalp and elbows since he was a teenager, which is not present currently. Laboratory investigation shows a normal complete blood cell count and blood chemistry panel. Sedimentation rate is increased to 40 mm/hour and C-reactive protein is increased to 10.7 mg/L. What is the most likely diagnosis for this man?
questions.solution: Asymmetrical joint involvement with the DIP joints affected would be mostly suggestive of psoriatic arthritis. The diffuse swelling of the great toe is suggestive of dactylitis, which is a characteristic of spondyloarthropathies and is not seen with any of the other listed conditions. The rash of psoriasis may not always be present at the time of diagnosis of psoriatic arthritis. The long duration of symptoms and involvement of the upper extremities is atypical for gout. Lyme disease arthritis most often presents as monoarthritis involving the knee; in cases where there is oligoarticular involvement, the DIP joints are not usually affected. The asymmetrical joint involvement and involvement of the DIP joints is unusual for rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with a history of an uncontrollable urge to move her legs, which occurs every night while lying in bed. Stretching her legs and walking offer temporary symptomatic relief, although sleep initiation is affected. She provides a history of heavy menstrual periods. Neurologic examination findings are normal for the lower limbs, including motor strength, reflexes, and sensation to vibration, joint position, pinprick, and temperature. What is the best next step in management of this patient?
questions.solution: The patient has a history that is consistent with restless legs syndrome. Of the answer choices provided, ferritin would be the most appropriate test, particularly in the context of heavy menstrual periods. The other tests are not appropriate under these circumstances, especially given the normal findings on neurologic examination.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male has massive splenomegaly with myeloid hyperplasia. What is the next best investigation to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is a case of massive splenomegaly with myeloid hyperplasia, suggestive of CML. Next investigation should be RT PCR or FISH to see t(9,22) i.e BCR-ABL translocation.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page Number-1093.

questions.text: Identify the following image:
questions.solution:
Image shows a Nexplanon with an applicator.

Nexplanon - It is a single rod implant containing 68 mg of etonogestrel. Initially releases 60-70 micrograms daily, gradually reduces to 25-30 micrograms after 3 years.

It is a long-acting, reversible contraceptive (LARC).

questions.text: All the following are disadvantages of mediolateral episiotomy except-
questions.solution: • As compared to median episiotomy, mediolateral episiotomy is relatively safe from rectal involvement.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with a symmetric, expansile cystic lesion in the proximal humerus. All the following can be done for his treatment except-
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation with a symmetric, expansile cystic lesion in the proximal humerus is indicative of a solitary bone cyst. The standard treatment options for a solitary bone cyst include curettage, intralesional steroids, and intralesional sclerosing agents. However, radiotherapy is generally not considered a primary treatment for solitary bone cysts.

Radiotherapy is reserved for specific cases and is not a routine intervention in the management of solitary bone cysts due to potential side effects. Therefore, the correct answer is D) Radiotherapy.

Reference: Chapman's Orthopaedic Surgery, 3rd Edition, Page Number 3392-3394.

choices.text: They serve as cofactors for enzymes involved in carbohydrate metabolism
They are involved in the regulation of gene expression by binding to specific DNA sequences
They facilitate electron transfer reactions in the electron transport chain
They act as antioxidants, scavenging free radicals in the body

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the role of zinc fingers in biochemical processes?
questions.solution:
• Zinc fingers are structural motifs that are commonly found in proteins involved in DNA binding and gene regulation.
  • They typically consist of a zinc ion coordinated by a specific arrangement of cysteine and histidine residues. This structural feature allows zinc fingers to bind to specific DNA sequences, thereby regulating gene expression.
  • Zinc fingers are not directly involved in other processes such as carbohydrate metabolism, electron transfer reactions, or acting as antioxidants.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page Number-437.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male has recurrent UTI. Cystoscopically, soft yellow, slightly raised mucosal plaques, 3 to 4 cm in diameter were seen. What will be the classical histological finding?
questions.solution:
Histologically, the lesion is composed of aggregates of large foamy macrophages with occasional multinucleated giant cells and lymphocytes. The macrophages have abundant granular cytoplasm due to phagosomes stuffed with particulate and membranous debris of bacterial origin, which are believed to accumulate due to defective phagolysosome function. In addition, laminated mineralized concretions resulting from deposition of calcium in enlarged lysosomes, known as Michaelis-Gutmann bodies, are typically present within the macrophages.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page Number-1118.

questions.text: A 52-year-old HIV-positive male complained of headache, confusion, and drowsiness for the last 3 days. There was an episode of loss of consciousness. On examination, he had a fever and neck stiffness. On CSF examination, mild lymphocytic meningitis was suspected. Which of the following CNS cell types express both CD4 co-receptor as well as CCR5/CXCR4 receptors?
questions.solution:
In HIV infection, among the CNS cell types, only microglia express both the CD4 co-receptor and the chemokine receptors (CCR5 or CXCR4) that are required for efficient infection by HIV.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page Number-1267.

questions.text: In a COPD patient, FEV1 50-80% of predicted falls under what severity of airflow limitation?
Which of the following is not included in the immunological domain in the 2019 ACR-EULAR criteria for SLE?
questions.solution: Direct Coomb's test is not a part of the immunological domain

questions.text: Which of the following adverse effects is likely to be due to a psychotropic drug inhibiting the reuptake of serotonin?
questions.solution:
Psychotropic drugs that inhibit the reuptake of serotonin, such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), are commonly used to treat depression, phobias, and other conditions. Unlike tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs), SSRIs have advantages, including no anticholinergic effects, sedation, weight gain, or propensity to cause seizures or arrhythmias. However, SSRIs can cause sexual dysfunction, including inhibition of ejaculation and anorgasmia.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page Number-487.

choices.text: Projectile vomiting is diagnostic of pyloric stenosis
Green-colored vomiting in a newborn is a sign of gastro-esophageal reflux
Vomiting is a presenting symptom of raised intracranial pressure
Cow milk protein intolerance does not cause vomiting in breastfed babies

questions.text: When assessing a child with vomiting, which of the following statements is true with respect to vomiting in a child?
questions.solution:
Vomiting can be a presenting symptom of raised intracranial pressure in a child. Projectile vomiting is associated with pyloric stenosis. Green-colored vomiting in a newborn is often a sign of intestinal obstruction, not gastroesophageal reflux. Cow milk protein intolerance can indeed cause vomiting in breastfed babies.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 20th Edition, Page Number-2950.

questions.text: The root of the mesentery crosses which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
The root of the mesentery is directed obliquely downwards and to the right. It crosses several structures including the third part of the duodenum, abdominal aorta, inferior vena cava, right ureter, and right psoas major muscle.


Extent

From duodenojejunal junction to the right sacro-iliac joint.

Structures crossed:

  • 3rd part of duodenum
  • Abdominal aorta
  • IVC
  • Right gonadal vessels
  • Right ureter
  • Right psoas major

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia: Human Anatomy, Volume-2, 8th Edition, Page Number-276.

questions.text: Which among the following conditions shows greenish discharge from the nipple?
questions.solution:
Duct ectasia is associated with a green or black secretion.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page Number-925.

questions.text: Which among the following carries slightly increased risk of invasive breast carcinoma based on the pathological examination of benign breast tissue?
questions.solution:
Papilloma carries a slightly increased risk of invasive breast cancer.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page Number-931.

questions.text: Which one of the following bacteria is classified as a facultative anaerobe?
questions.solution:
Escherichia coli (E. coli) is an example of a facultative anaerobe. Facultative anaerobes prefer aerobic conditions but can also grow in anaerobic environments. Understanding the oxygen requirements of different bacteria is essential for cultivating them in laboratory settings.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page Number-276.

questions.text: Which of the following curvatures are primary in nature?
questions.solution:
The primary curves of the vertebral column are present at birth and include the thoracic and sacral curves, both of which are concave forwards. The secondary or compensatory curves, which develop later, are the cervical and lumbar curves, both of which are convex forwards.


Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia: Human Anatomy, Volume-1, 8th Edition, Page Number-228.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with generalized edema, urine protein +3, serum cholesterol 250 mg/dl. Urine routine examination shows oval fat bodies. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of generalized edema, significant proteinuria (+3), elevated serum cholesterol, and the presence of oval fat bodies in urine is indicative of nephrotic syndrome. Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by increased glomerular permeability to proteins, leading to massive proteinuria and subsequent edema.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 20th Edition, Page Number-2521

questions.text: What will be the position of the appendix in silent appendicitis?
questions.solution:
Retrocecal

  • Rigidity is often absent, and even application of deep pressure may fail to elicit tenderness (silent appendix), the reason being that the caecum, distended with gas, prevents the pressure exerted by the hand from reaching the inflamed structure in case of retrocecal appendix.
  • However, deep tenderness is often present in the loin, and rigidity of the quadratus lumborum may be in evidence.
  • Psoas spasm, due to the inflamed appendix being in contact with that muscle, may be sufficient to cause flexion of the hip joint.
  • Hyperextension of the hip joint may induce abdominal pain when the degree of psoas spasm is insufficient to cause flexion of the hip.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page Number-1339.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most useful method to combat digitalis cardio-toxicity?
questions.solution:
Digitalis toxicity can lead to severe cardiac effects. Digoxin-specific antibody, Digibind, is highly effective in reversing cardiotoxicity due to digitalis and related glycosides. The Fab fragment of Digibind lacks the Fc fragment, making it nonimmunogenic. It binds with high affinity to digitalis, forming a complex that is then cleared by the kidneys. This specific reversal agent has markedly improved the survival of seriously digitalis-intoxicated patients.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page Number-560.

questions.text: Which is the most common site involved in tinea cruris infection?
questions.solution:
Tinea cruris occurs most frequently in the inguinal areas of obese men during warm weather. Heat, friction, and maceration all predispose to its development.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page Number-1169.

questions.text: Civatte bodies are seen in which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Lichen planus (LP) is an inflammatory disorder of the skin and mucous membranes with no known cause. It appears as pruritic, violaceous papules and plaques most commonly found on the wrists, lower back, and ankles. A lattice-like network of white lines called Wickham striae overlies the lesions but is most easily observed on the buccal mucosa. In lichen planus, civatte bodies, also known as colloid or cytoid bodies, are seen. These bodies are anucleate, necrotic basal cells that may become incorporated into the inflamed papillary dermis.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page Number-1158

questions.text: What is a safe method for disposal of mercury?
questions.solution:
Safe disposal of mercury involves collecting it carefully and recycling it. It involves carefully collecting mercury-containing items, such as thermometers or fluorescent light bulbs, and sending them to specialized facilities for recycling or proper disposal, minimizing the release of mercury into the environment and facilitating its reuse in manufacturing processes.

Incorrect options:

Option B) Controlled combustion: Burning mercury-containing materials can release toxic mercury vapor into the air, posing serious health risks to humans and the environment. Controlled combustion is not a safe method for disposing of mercury.

Option C) Treatment with chemicals: Treating mercury with chemicals can sometimes lead to the formation of more hazardous compounds or by-products. Chemical treatments may not effectively neutralize or eliminate the toxicity of mercury, and improper handling can result in environmental contamination.

Option D) Deep burial: Burial of mercury-containing materials can lead to contamination of soil and groundwater, posing long-term environmental risks. Mercury can leach into the surrounding environment over time, potentially impacting ecosystems and human health.

Therefore, option A (Collect carefully and recycle) is the best method for safe disposal of mercury.

questions.text: All are incinerated except-
questions.solution:
Broken ampoules are not typically incinerated.

Broken ampoules: While broken ampoules are not typically considered biohazardous or infectious waste. Instead, broken ampoules can often be recycled or disposed of as hazardous waste through specialized programs or facilities.

Incorrect options:

Option A) Human anatomical waste: Human anatomical waste, such as body parts or tissues removed during surgery, is often considered biohazardous and is typically disposed of through incineration. This helps prevent the spread of infectious diseases and ensures proper handling of potentially hazardous materials.

Option B) Animal waste: Animal waste, including carcasses and tissues from veterinary clinics or research laboratories, is often incinerated to minimise the risk of disease transmission and to comply with regulations for the safe disposal of animal remains.

Option C) Infected solid waste: Waste contaminated with infectious agents or biomedical materials, such as used bandages, dressings, or laboratory specimens, is commonly incinerated to eliminate pathogens and reduce the risk of spreading infections to humans or animals.

Therefore, option D is the correct answer because broken thermometers are not typically incinerated due to their classification as hazardous waste containing mercury. Instead, they require proper handling and disposal to prevent environmental contamination and human exposure to Mercury.

questions.text: Mild poisoning by organophosphate occurs when the cholinesterase activity is
questions.solution:
• Mild poisoning usually occurs when cholinesterase activity is 20 to 50% of the normal.
  • Moderate poisoning occurs when activity is 10 to 20% of the normal.
  • Severe poisoning when activity is less than 10% the normal.

Small, repeated exposures may gradually depress the cholinesterase activity to very low levels, often resulting in minimal symptoms.

References: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology by KS Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page Number-396.

questions.text: The ECG below is diagnostic of-
questions.solution: In Mobitz type 1 Heart block/ Wenckebach Phenomenon, gradually progressive PR interval prolongation occurs before the blocked sinus impulse, with the greatest PR increment typically occurring between the first and second beats of a cycle, gradually decreasing in subsequent beats. Shortening of the PR interval occurs after the blocked sinus impulse, provided that the P wave is conducted to the ventricle.

questions.text: Most common chronic dermatitis in Lupus is-
questions.solution: Lupus dermatitis can be classified as acute, subacute, or chronic, and there are many different types of lesions encompassed within these groups. Discoid lupus erythematosus (DLE) is the most common chronic dermatitis in lupus; lesions are roughly circular with slightly raised, scaly hyperpigmented erythematous rim and depigmented, atrophic centers in which all dermal appendages are permanently destroyed

Investigations and interpretation of SUI:

  1. Q tip test positive (>30)

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient came to the emergency department with severe elbow pain and swelling. His X-ray was taken immediately. All the following are complications of the injury except-
questions.solution:
Complications of elbow injuries include myositis ossificans, median nerve injury, and brachial artery injury. Radial nerve injury is not a typical complication of an elbow injury. The radial nerve is more commonly associated with humeral shaft fractures.

questions.text: A man presented to an STD clinic with urethritis and urethral discharge. Gram stain shows numerous pus cells but no microorganisms. The culture is negative on routine media. The most likely agent is-

Understanding the specific diagnostic features of different sexually transmitted infections is crucial for accurate diagnosis and treatment.

questions.text: All the following are pillars of primary health care except-
questions.solution:
Health education is indeed a fundamental aspect of primary health care, and it is considered as one of the pillars, alongside equitable distribution, community participation, and intersectoral coordination.

Incorrect options:

Option A) Equitable distribution: This is a key principle of primary health care, emphasizing the fair allocation of healthcare resources and services to ensure that everyone has access to essential healthcare regardless of socioeconomic status, geography, or other factors.

Option B) Community participation: In primary health care, community participation is vital for ensuring that healthcare services meet the needs and preferences of the local population. It involves engaging community members in decision-making processes, empowering them to take ownership of their health, and fostering partnerships between healthcare providers and the community.

Option D) Intersectoral coordination: Primary health care recognizes that improving health outcomes requires collaboration across multiple sectors beyond healthcare, such as education, housing, agriculture, and transportation. Intersectoral coordination involves integrating efforts and resources from various sectors to address the social determinants of health and promote holistic well-being.

In summary, health education is indeed an integral component of primary health care, and the other options (equitable distribution, community participation, and intersectoral coordination) are all recognized pillars of primary health care as well.

questions.text: In which situation it is considered that the emphasis has shifted from urban to rural services?
questions.solution: Equitable distribution: The Equitable Distribution of Resources refers to the fair allocation of resources such as wealth, healthcare, education, and opportunities across all segments of society, irrespective of gender, race, social status, or any other differentiating factor. This is not to be confused with equal distribution, which means everyone gets the same amount. Instead, it is about fairness, ensuring everyone can access the resources they need to thrive.

questions.text: Blue lines are not seen in poisoning by-
questions.solution:
Blue lines are not seen in Arsenic poisoning.

Burton's or Burtonian line:

Morphology:

  • A stippled blue line (or bluish black) is seen on gums in 50-70% cases of chronic lead poisoning (Plumbism/saturnism).

Characteristics:

  • More common in the upper jaw
  • Appears within a week of exposure
  • Not seen in edentulous persons
  • Removal from exposure obliterates the line gradually
  • More common in persons with bad orodental hygiene and carious teeth

Mechanism:

Subepithelial deposition of black lead granules.

Bad oral hygiene-food sticking in gums decomposition → H2S formed → Reacts with lead in tissues forms lead sulphide [black].

Differential diagnosis:

  • Similar lines seen in poisoning by bismuth, copper, iron, mercury and silver (due to formation of sulphides of each). In copper poisoning, it is green in colour, known as Clapton's lines

Reference: Textbook of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology by Anil Aggrawal, Page Number-624.

questions.text: Which statement is false regarding autoantibodies in SLE?
questions.solution:
Diagnostically, the most important autoantibodies to detect SLE are ANA because the test is positive in >95% of patients, usually at the onset of symptoms. A few patients develop ANA within 1 year of symptom onset; repeated testing may thus be useful. ANA tests using immunofluorescent methods are more reliable than enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays (ELISAs) and/or bead assays, which have less specificity. ANA-negative lupus exists but is rare in adults and is usually associated with other autoantibodies (anti-Ro or anti-DNA).

High-titer IgG antibodies to double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) (but not to single-stranded DNA) are specific for SLE. Antibodies to Sm are specific for SLE and assist in diagnosis; anti-Sm antibodies do not usually correlate with disease activity or clinical manifestations

questions.text: A child was advised yearly vaccination with a vaccine, which is not a part of the national immunization schedule. Yearly vaccination is recommended against?
questions.solution:
Annual vaccination is given against influenza vaccine in selected high-risk groups.

  • The type of influenza vaccine currently marketed for use in India is an inactivated, quadrivalent vaccine.
  • The vaccines are highly immunogenic and safe for use above 6 months of age.
  • The vaccine is not a part of the National Immunization Schedule, but is recommended by the IAP in selected high-risk groups like;

questions.text: Which of the following monoclonal antibodies is approved for the reversal of serious bleeding due to dabigatran toxicity?
questions.solution:
Idarucizumab is a specific reversal agent for dabigatran, a direct oral anticoagulant. It is a humanized mouse monoclonal antibody fragment that binds dabigatran with high affinity. The idarucizumab-dabigatran complex is essentially irreversible, and is cleared by the kidneys. Administered as intravenous boluses, idarucizumab rapidly reverses the anticoagulant effects of dabigatran. This is crucial in situations where urgent reversal is needed, such as in cases of serious bleeding.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th Edition, Page Number-720.

questions.text: Which among the following diseases shows "claw sign" on barium enema study?
questions.solution:
Imaging in intussusception

  • A plain abdominal field usually reveals evidence of small or large bowel obstruction, with an absent cecal gas shadow in ileocolic cases.
  • A soft tissue opacity is often visible in children.
  • A barium enema may be used to diagnose the presence of an ileocolic intussusception (the claw sign) but does not demonstrate small bowel intussusception.
  • An abdominal ultrasound scan has a high diagnostic sensitivity in children, demonstrating the typical doughnut appearance of concentric rings in the transverse section.
  • CT scanning is currently considered the most sensitive radiological method to confirm intussusception, with a reported diagnostic accuracy of 58-100%.
  • The characteristic features of CT scan include a 'target'- or 'sausage'- shaped soft-tissue mass with a layering effect; mesenteric vessels within the bowel lumen are also typical.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page Number 1384-1385.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man has been having problems breathing through the nose for a few months. Sometimes, epistaxis also occurs. On general examination, the left cervical lymph node is enlarged. On CT-scan, a 3 cm mass is noted in the left nasopharynx. On biopsy of this mass, large epithelial cells with round vesicular nuclei and prominent nucleoli are seen, as shown in the image below. Abundant lymphocytes are also seen infiltrating the lesion, as shown in the image. Radiotherapy is advised. Which of the following viruses play the most important role in the development of this condition?
questions.solution:
It is a case of nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is associated with Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) infection. Histologically, the undifferentiated variant is composed of large epithelial cells with oval or round vesicular nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and indistinct cell borders.

Abundant, normal-appearing lymphocytes, predominantly T cells, infiltrate the tumors.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page Number 741-742.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male patient presents with complaints of poor voiding, straining, hesitancy, and increased frequency. USG shows the following image. What is the finding seen in this image?
questions.solution:
Bladder diverticulum is demonstrated by ultrasound.

  • A bladder outlet obstruction causes hypertrophy of the bladder wall and increases intravesical pressure to as high as 150 cm H2. This results in the formation of a pulsion diverticulum.
  • The mouth of the diverticulum is usually situated above and to the outer side of one ureteric orifice.
  • Exceptionally, it is near the midline behind the interureteric ridge.
  • An uninfected diverticulum of the bladder usually causes no symptoms.

Complications -

  • Recurrent urinary tract infections, as the pouch cannot empty itself completely.
  • Bladder stones
  • Peridiverticulitis can cause dense adhesions between the diverticulum and surrounding structures.
  • Squamous cell metaplasia and neoplasia are infrequent complications.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page Number-1491.

questions.text: Inflammasome has been implicated in which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
The inflammasome has been implicated in various diseases, including gout (inflammatory reactions to urate crystals), obesity-associated type 2 diabetes (inflammatory reactions to lipids), and Alzheimer's disease (inflammatory reactions to amyloid deposits in the brain).

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page Number-74

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is transmitted globally by all mosquitoes?
questions.solution:
Option B) Filariasis: Filariasis, also known as lymphatic filariasis or elephantiasis, is a disease caused by parasitic worms transmitted to humans through the bites of infected mosquitoes. Several mosquito species, including various types of Anopheles, Culex, and Aedes mosquitoes, can serve as vectors for transmitting filariasis. Therefore, filariasis is transmitted globally by multiple species of mosquitoes.

Incorrect options:

Option A) Malaria: Malaria is primarily transmitted by Anopheles mosquitoes. While malaria is a significant global health concern and is endemic in many regions where Anopheles mosquitoes are prevalent, it is not transmitted globally by all mosquitoes.

Option C) Yellow fever: Yellow fever is primarily transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes, particularly Aedes aegypti. While yellow fever can cause outbreaks in certain regions where Aedes mosquitoes are prevalent, it is not transmitted globally by all mosquitoes.

Option D) Dengue fever: Dengue fever is also primarily transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes, particularly Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus. Similar to yellow fever, dengue fever outbreaks occur in regions where Aedes mosquitoes are abundant but are not transmitted globally by all mosquitoes.

In summary, while malaria, yellow fever, and dengue fever are transmitted by specific species of mosquitoes, filariasis is transmitted globally by multiple species of mosquitoes, making it the correct answer to the question.

questions.text: What is the nerve supply to the marked structure in the given image?
questions.solution:
In the provided specimen, the marked structure corresponds to the trochlea, the pulley-like structure through which the tendon of the superior oblique muscle passes. The superior oblique muscle is responsible for the downward and outward movement of the eye. The nerve supplying the superior oblique muscle is the trochlear nerve, which is the 4th cranial nerve.

This nerve plays a crucial role in the intricate coordination of eye movements.

Reference: Gray's Anatomy E-book, 41st Edition, Page Number-669.

questions.text: Which among the following arteries gives a branch to the inferior thyroid artery?
questions.solution:
• Blood and Lymphatic Supply: The thyroid gland has a rich blood supply, and a complex network of vessels. It receives arterial blood from several sources.
  • Superior Thyroid Arteries: The superior thyroid arteries arise from the external carotid arteries. These arteries split into branches as they enter the upper poles of the thyroid lobes.
  • Inferior Thyroid Arteries: The inferior thyroid arteries originate from the thyrocervical trunks of the subclavian arteries. They branch fairly close to the thyrocervical trunk, and their course takes them upward and posteriorly, running behind the carotid sheath. They then turn and enter the mid-portion of the thyroid lobes.
  • Thyroidea ima Artery: In about 2% of individuals, a third artery known as the thyroidea ima artery can be present. This artery has an unusual origin, arising directly from either the aorta or innominate artery. It follows a midline path and enters either the thyroid isthmus or the lower poles of the thyroid lobes.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page Number-876.

questions.text: A child is below the third percentile for height. His growth velocity is normal, but chronological age is more than his skeletal age. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
In a child with normal growth velocity but a discrepancy between chronological age and skeletal age, the most likely diagnosis is constitutional delay in growth. This condition is characterized by delayed skeletal maturation without an underlying pathological cause. It often resolves with time, and affected individuals eventually catch up in height.

questions.text: The X-ray shown is suggestive of ?
questions.solution:
Renal osteodystrophy combines features of secondary hyperparathyroidism, rickets, osteomalacia, and osteoporosis. Renal retention of phosphate results in hyperphosphatemia, which reduces serum ionized calcium levels, therefore inducing hyperparathyroidism. The hyperparathyroidism increases bone resorption, which may normalize serum calcium levels by releasing the osseous storage of calcium. The various sites of bone resorption include the subperiosteal region of the phalanges, the phalangeal tufts, proximal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus, distal clavicle, and calvarial trabeculae.

If parathormone levels are mildly elevated over a longer period of time, its effect on bone tends to be anabolic. These effects include excessive maturation of osteoblasts leading to new bone formation and increased laying down of osteoid, which calcifies under the influence of secondarily elevated serum calcium levels. This patient has classic endplate involvement, which results in the appearance of "Rugger jersey."

questions.text: How many sputum samples are needed for the diagnosis of TB?
questions.solution:
2 sputum samples: This option aligns with the standard practice recommended by RNTCP. Collecting two sputum samples allows for increased sensitivity in detecting Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the causative agent of TB, and is considered adequate for initial diagnosis.

Incorrect options-

Option A) 1 sputum sample: While it is possible to detect tuberculosis with just one sputum sample, the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Program (RNTCP) in India typically recommends collecting two sputum samples for initial diagnosis. This is because having multiple samples increases the likelihood of detecting the bacteria responsible for TB, especially considering the intermittent shedding of the bacteria in sputum.

Option C) 3 sputum samples: While collecting three sputum samples may increase the chances of detecting TB bacteria, it is not typically necessary for initial diagnosis under RNTCP guidelines. Usually, if the first two samples are negative, additional diagnostic tests may be considered rather than collecting a third sample.

Option D) 4 sputum samples: Collecting four sputum samples is not a standard practice for diagnosing TB under RNTCP guidelines. It would be excessive and impractical in most cases. The program aims for a balance between diagnostic sensitivity and practicality in resource-limited settings.

In summary, while it is possible to diagnose TB with just one sputum sample, the standard practice recommended by RNTCP is to collect two sputum samples for initial diagnosis. This option provides a balance between diagnostic accuracy and practicality in resource-limited settings, making it the most appropriate choice.

questions.text: Most commonly affected vessel in Takayasu arteritis is -
Which part of the gastrointestinal tract cancer occurs due to Crohn's disease?
questions.solution:
• Long-standing Crohn's disease predisposes to cancer of the small intestine and colon.
  • These carcinomas typically arise at sites of chronic disease and more commonly occur in the ileum as a result of the chronic inflammation of the mucosa.
  • Most are not detected until in advanced stages, and the prognosis is poor.
  • Although the relative risk for small bowel cancer in Crohn's disease is approximately 100-fold, the absolute risk is still small.
  • Of greater concern is the development of colorectal cancer in patients with colonic involvement and a long duration of disease.
  • Dysplasia is the putative precursor lesion for Crohn's disease-associated cancer. Patients with long-standing Crohn's disease should have an equally aggressive colonoscopic surveillance regimen as patients with extensive ulcerative colitis.
  • Small bowel adenocarcinoma associated with Crohn's disease has an aggressive behavior and a strong probability of extracellular mucin.
  • In surgical specimens from patients with Crohn's disease, mucinous-appearing anal fistulas and ileal areas of adhesion/retraction should always be closely examined by a pathologist to evaluate for dysplasia or malignancy.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page Number-1261.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true with respect to disaster management?
questions.solution:
Option B) Response in pre-disaster phase: Response activities occur after a disaster strikes, not in the pre-disaster phase. Response involves immediate actions to address the emergency needs of affected populations, such as search and rescue, medical care, shelter provision, and distribution of relief supplies. Therefore, response activities do not take place before a disaster occurs.

The term "response" specifically refers to actions taken in the immediate aftermath of a disaster to address its impact and provide assistance to affected individuals and communities. Pre-disaster activities focus on preparedness measures, such as planning, training, and capacity-building, rather than response activities. Therefore, response activities do not occur in the pre-disaster phase.

Incorrect options:

Option A) Mitigation before a disaster strikes: Mitigation refers to actions taken to reduce or eliminate the risk and impact of disasters. This includes measures such as building codes, land-use planning, early warning systems, and community preparedness initiatives. Mitigation efforts are indeed conducted before a disaster occurs to minimize its potential effects.

Option C) Yellow colour is for medium priority: In disaster management, color-coded triage tags are often used to categorize patients based on the severity of their injuries or medical needs. Yellow is typically assigned to indicate patients with moderate injuries or conditions that require medical attention but are not immediately life-threatening. Therefore, yellow is indeed used to represent medium priority in triage.

Option D) Gastroenteritis is the commonest infection after disaster Gastroenteritis, an inflammation of the stomach and intestines typically caused by viral or bacterial infections, is indeed a common health issue following disasters, especially in situations where access to clean water and sanitation is compromised. Therefore, it is true that gastroenteritis is one of the most common infections observed after disasters.

questions.text: All the following are systemic effects of inflammation except:
questions.solution:
Systemic effects of inflammation include fever, elevated acute-phase proteins (CRP, fibrinogen, serum amyloid A), leukocytosis, increased pulse and blood pressure, decreased sweating (due to redirection of blood flow from cutaneous to deep vascular beds), rigors, chills, anorexia, somnolence, malaise, etc.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page Number-102.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man reports brief but severe attacks of stabbing pain over his left eye lasting for 2 to 3 minutes occurring on a daily basis for the past 3 weeks. The pain attack is followed by complete resolution, although another attack may occur immediately afterward. In general, the headaches occur from 10 to 20 times per day without a clear diurnal pattern. Just prior to the pain, he notices that his left eye becomes red, although he does not notice any tearing. His left eyelid does, however, appear somewhat swollen during attacks. An MRI of the brain is normal. Which of the following medications would most likely be effective in treating this man's headache disorder?
questions.solution: This patient most likely has a short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache with cranial autonomic features (SUNA), like short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache with conjunctival injection and tearing (SUNCT) only without both conjunctival injection and tearing. Characteristic features of SUNA seen in this case include brief but rapidly recurrent severe stabbing pain with ipsilateral autonomic features without a response to sumatriptan. Given this, the medication most likely to be effective would be lamotrigine. Lithium is used to prevent cluster headache, while indomethacin is useful in treating hemicrania continua and paroxysmal hemicrania. Prednisone could be considered for bridge therapy in treating cluster headaches.

questions.text: All the following statements regarding Kawasaki disease are true except:
questions.solution:
Kawasaki disease is a systemic vasculitis that primarily affects children. It can occur in outbreaks, is more common in children under 5 years, and can lead to acquired heart disease. However, Kawasaki disease is not contagious, and exposure to an affected person does not increase the risk. The exact cause is unknown, but it is believed to involve an abnormal immune response.

choices.text: T follicular helper cells in germinal centers

questions.text: Which of the following acts as reservoir/s of HIV?
questions.solution:
Reservoirs of HIV involve specific immune cells that play a role in the persistence of the virus.

  • Follicular Dendritic Cells (FDCs): FDCs, found in germinal centers of lymph nodes, can act as reservoirs of HIV. These cells have receptors for the Fc portion of immunoglobulins, allowing them to trap HIV virions coated with anti-HIV antibodies.
  • T Follicular Helper (TFH) Cells: Infected TFH cells in germinal centers are also considered reservoirs of HIV. These cells, which are a subset of CD4+ T cells, can harbor the virus and contribute to its persistence.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page Number-252.

questions.text: Which of these census reports is used as a source of data?
questions.solution:
Census reports are a classic example of secondary data because they are collected by government agencies or organizations for purposes other than the researcher's specific study. Researchers often use Census data as a secondary source to provide context, background information, or to analyse trends within a population without directly collecting the data themselves.

Incorrect options-

Option A) Primary data: Primary data refers to data that is collected firsthand by the researcher for a specific purpose. It involves direct interaction with the source of data, such as surveys, interviews, experiments, or observations. Census reports are not collected directly by researchers but are conducted by government agencies or organizations to gather demographic information about a population. Therefore, census reports are not considered primary data.

Option C) Organized data: Organized data refers to data that has been structured or arranged in a systematic manner for easy access and analysis. While census reports are indeed organized, this term does not specifically describe the nature of the data itself but rather how it is presented or managed. Census reports can contain both primary and secondary data, depending on how the information was collected and compiled.

Option D) Raw data: Raw data refers to unprocessed and unanalyzed data that is collected directly from the source. Census reports typically undergo processing, aggregation, and analysis before they are published and made available to users. Therefore, census reports are not considered raw data.

questions.text: A 5-year-old male child, with a coagulation disorder presents to the emergency unit with groin pain after a minor trauma to his back. questions.text: Match the following tumor suppressor genes and diseases caused by their mutations
questions.solution:
APC (Adenomatous Polyposis Coli): Mutations in the APC gene are associated with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), an autosomal dominant disorder leading to the development of numerous colonic polyps and an increased risk of colon carcinoma.

VHL (Von Hippel-Lindau): Mutations in the VHL gene cause von Hippel-Lindau syndrome, an autosomal dominant disorder linked to a high risk of renal cell carcinoma and pheochromocytoma.

PTEN (Phosphatase and Tensin Homolog): Germline mutations in PTEN are associated with Cowden syndrome, an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by a high risk of breast and endometrial carcinoma.

E-cadherin: Germline mutations in the E-cadherin gene (CDH1) cause autosomal dominant familial gastric carcinoma. Loss of CDH1 expression is also observed in sporadic carcinomas, leading to increased invasiveness.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page Number-299

questions.text: Which among the following is the characteristic feature of asplenia?
questions.solution:
Filtration

  • The splenic filtration process includes removal of senescent cells, cellular inclusions (e.g., RBC nucleoli), and parasites, and the sequestration of RBCs (for maturation) and platelets (reservoir). The plasma is directed to the lymphoid tissue, where soluble antigens stimulate the production of antibodies.
  • RBC morphology and RBC function is maintained by splenic filtration. Normal RBCs are biconcave and deform easily. This plasticity allows passage through the microvasculature and optimizes the exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide.
  • Imperfect RBCs with inclusions such as nucleoli, Howell-Jolly bodies (nuclear remnant), Heinz bodies (denatured hemoglobin), Pappenheimer bodies (iron granules), acanthocytes (spur cells), codocytes (target cells), and stippling cause these RBCs to undergo cleansing in the spleen.
  • The presence of Howell-Jolly bodies on a peripheral blood smear is one of the most characteristic findings for asplenia; surgical or medical (hemoglobinopathies).
  • Howell-Jolly bodies are strongly basophilic inclusion bodies found in the cytoplasm of RBCs, and represent nuclei remnants that were unable to be cleared by a functioning spleen. Aged RBCs with decreased plasticity (>120 days) become trapped and destroyed in the spleen. Abnormal erythrocytes that result from hemoglobinopathies such as sickle cell anemia, hereditary spherocytosis, thalassemia, or pyruvate kinase deficiency (PKD) are also trapped and destroyed by the spleen. The overall effect is worsening anemia, splenomegaly, and sometimes autoinfarction of the spleen. Similarly, the spleen is involved in platelet destruction in immune thrombocytopenia (ITP), formerly known as idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page Number-1570.

questions.text: 'Clean care is safer care' guidelines given by WHO is for:-
questions.solution:
The "Clean care is safer care" guidelines provided by the World Health Organisation (WHO) primarily focus on hand hygiene practices to ensure patient safety and prevent Healthcare- Associated Infections (HAIs). Hand hygiene is recognized as one of the most effective measures to prevent the spread of infections in healthcare settings. The guidelines emphasize the importance of proper hand hygiene techniques among healthcare workers, patients, and visitors to minimize the risk of transmission of harmful pathogens.

Incorrect options:

Option B) Obstetric care: While hand hygiene is essential in obstetric care, the specific "Clean care is safer care" guidelines are not solely dedicated to obstetric care. Hand hygiene is crucial in all aspects of healthcare to prevent infections, not just in obstetrics.

Option C) Cord care: Cord care guidelines focus on the prevention of infections related to umbilical cord care in newborns. While hand hygiene is important in this context, the "Clean care is safer care" guidelines are broader and encompass all aspects of hand hygiene in healthcare settings.

Option D) Injection practices: Injection safety is indeed a critical aspect of healthcare, but the "Clean care is safer care" guidelines primarily emphasize hand hygiene practices. Injection safety may be addressed in other WHO guidelines specifically dedicated to safe injection practices.

questions.text: For determining the maturity of a newborn at birth, which of the following index/scoring is used?
questions.solution:
The Ballard scoring system, also known as the Dubowitz score, is commonly used to assess the maturity of a newborn at birth. It involves a comprehensive examination of physical and neuromuscular characteristics to estimate gestational age. The Ponderal index is used to evaluate the growth pattern in small-for-gestational-age (SGA) babies, Bhutani scoring is used for neonatal hyperbilirubinemia, and Mallampati scoring is used to determine the size of the tongue relative to the oropharynx.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 20th Edition, Page Number-824.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented to the OPD with a 2 cm thyroid nodule. She was euthyroid. Family history for thyroid cancer is positive. On FNAC, diagnosis of medullary thyroid carcinoma was given, and hence, total thyroidectomy was performed. Point mutation in which of the following proto-oncogenes is a possibility?
questions.solution:
Medullary thyroid carcinomas (MTC) are associated with mutations in the RET proto-oncogene. Medullary thyroid carcinoma can be sporadic or familial. Approximately 25% of cases are familial, and these are often associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A (MEN 2A) or type 2B (MEN 2B) syndromes.

RET Proto-oncogene: Activating mutations in the RET proto-oncogene, which codes for a receptor tyrosine kinase, are a hallmark of medullary thyroid carcinoma. In familial cases, the mutation is often inherited.

KIT, HGF, KRAS: While mutations in other genes like KIT (seen in gastrointestinal stromal tumors), HGF (associated with hepatocellular carcinomas and thyroid cancer), and KRAS (commonly mutated in various cancers like colon, lung, and pancreatic tumors) may be involved in other malignancies, they are not specifically associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page Number-285.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the epidemiology of amoebic liver abscess?
questions.solution:
Epidemiologic studies specifically addressing E. histolytica infections have estimated that as many as 55% of those in endemic regions are infected, although less than 50% are symptomatic.

In contrast to pyogenic hepatic abscesses, patients with amoebic liver abscesses tend to be Hispanic men, 20 to 40 years of age, with a history of travel to (or origination from) an endemic area.

Poverty and cramped living conditions are associated with higher rates of infection.

A male preponderance of more than 10:1 has been reported in almost all studies.

For unclear reasons, menstruating women have a low incidence of invasive amebiasis, and pregnancy appears to abrogate this resistance.

Heavy alcohol consumption is commonly reported and may render the liver more susceptible to amoebic infection.

Patients with impaired host immunity also appear to be at higher risk of infection and have higher mortality rates.

Patients with amoebic liver abscess without a history of travel to an endemic area often have associated immunosuppression, such as human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection, malnutrition, chronic infection, or chronic steroid use.


Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page Number-1457.

questions.text: Which among the following statements is false for ulcerative type of intestinal tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Ulcerative tuberculosis

  • Ulcerative tuberculosis develops secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis, and arises as a result of swallowing tubercle bacilli.
  • Multiple ulcers, lying transversely, develop in the terminal ileum and the overlying serosa is thickened, reddened and covered in tubercles.
  • Patients typically present with diarrhea and weight loss, although subacute obstruction and even local perforation and fistula formation can occur.
  • A barium follow-through or CT examination fails to show filling of the lower ileum, caecum and the ascending colon as a result of narrowing of the ulcerated segment.
  • A course of anti tuberculous chemotherapy usually leads to cure, provided the pulmonary tuberculosis is adequately treated.
  • Surgery is usually undertaken only in the rare event of a perforation or complete intestinal obstruction.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page Number-1308.

questions.text:
What is the chronology of steps involved in a planning cycle?
A. Monitoring and Evaluation
B. Programming and Implementation
C. Assessment of resources
D. Analysis of existing health situation
questions.solution:
Analysis of existing health situation (D): This step involves assessing the current health status, identifying health problems, determining their causes, and understanding the factors influencing health outcomes. It provides the foundation for the planning process by highlighting priority areas that need attention.

Assessment of resources (C): After understanding the existing health situation, the next step is to assess the available resources such as personnel, facilities, finances, and equipment. This assessment helps in determining the capacity and constraints for addressing the identified health issues.

Programming and Implementation (B): Based on the analysis of the health situation and assessment of resources, programs and interventions are planned and developed. This step involves designing strategies, setting objectives, defining activities, and establishing timelines for implementation.

Monitoring and Evaluation (A): Once programs are implemented, it is essential to monitor their progress and evaluate their effectiveness. Monitoring involves tracking the implementation process, while evaluation assesses the impact and outcomes of the programs. This step helps in identifying successes, challenges, and areas for improvement, informing future planning cycles.

Therefore, the correct sequence is b. DCBA because it follows the logical progression of steps in the planning cycle, starting with analyzing the health situation, assessing resources, programming and implementation, and ending with monitoring and evaluation. The other options do not follow this logical sequence.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with a history of poor night vision, dryness of the eyes, and frequent upper respiratory tract infections. Physical examination reveals follicular hyperkeratosis on the skin. Which of the following biochemical abnormalities is most likely associated with this presentation?
questions.solution:
• Deficiency Manifestations of Vitamin A:
    • Stages of eye damage
      • Night Blindness or Nyctalopia Visual acuity is diminished in dim light. The patient cannot read or drive a car in poor light. The dark adaptation time is increased.
      • Xerophthalmia, the conjunctiva becomes dry, thick and wrinkled. The conjunctiva gets keratinized and loses its normal transparency. Dryness spreads to the cornea. It becomes glazy and lustreless due to keratinization of corneal epithelium. Infections may supersede.
      • Bitot's Spots- These are seen as grayish-white triangular plaques firmly adherent to the conjunctiva. This is due to increased thickness of conjunctiva in certain areas. All the ocular changes mentioned so far are completely reversible when vitamin is supplemented.
      • Keratomalacia -When the xerophthalmia persists for a long time, it progresses to keratomalacia (softening of the cornea). There is degeneration of corneal epithelium which may get vascularized.
      • Later, corneal opacities Bacterial infection leads to corneal ulceration, perforation of cornea and total blindness.
    • Skin conditions:
      • Vitamin A deficiency leads to hyperkeratosis and phrynoderma.
      • Dermatologic problems such as acne are effectively treated with retinoic acid or its derivatives.
      • Mild cases of acne and skin aging are treated with tretinoin (all-trans retinoic acid).

Reference: Lippincott Illustrated Review Biochemistry, 7th Edition, Chapter No: 28, Page Number-388.
